'}, {'created': '2015-11-11 08:39:55.000000000', 'message': "Move to template-based configuration of devops environments

To create a devops virtual environment (networks, volumes, nodes),
now can be used YAML template desctibed in [1].

How it can be used:

* New approach, environment will be created using the data from
  full_config object:

  environment.create_environment(full_config)

* Old-style approach (deprecated), in this case at first will be
  created a 'full_config' object using shell environment variables,
  and then called environment.create_environment(full_config):

  environment.describe_environment(boot_from='cdrom'):

* Override old-style approach, in this case the YAML config will
  be taken from the file located in DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE shell
  environment variable instead of variables from settings.py:

  export DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE=/tmp/some_template_file.yaml

- add create_envoronment() method that creates environment from
  provided config
- add template generator for keep legacy behaviour of the
  method describe_environment()
- Environment.define() is deprecated and left for back compatibility
  with older fuel-qa branches
- Some objects in template require the extended database schema,
  so in this patch there are some workarounds to use templates with
  original schema (particular data from address_pools and
  l2_network_devices are stored in the Network model)

[1] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240170/

Change-Id: Iad081bee94c4d3b404eda57b7c1c31011b837ba7
Implements: blueprint template-based-testcases
"}, {'created': '2015-11-11 08:48:48.000000000', 'message': "Move to template-based configuration of devops environments

To create a devops virtual environment (networks, volumes, nodes),
now can be used YAML template desctibed in [1].

How it can be used:

* New approach, environment will be created using the data from
  full_config object:

  environment.create_environment(full_config)

* Old-style approach (deprecated), in this case at first will be
  created a 'full_config' object using shell environment variables,
  and then called environment.create_environment(full_config):

  environment.describe_environment(boot_from='cdrom'):

* Override old-style approach, in this case the YAML config will
  be read from the file located in DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE shell
  environment variable to the 'full_config' object and passed to
  create_environment(full_config); creating config in old-style
  will be skipped:

  export DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE=/tmp/some_template_file.yaml

- add create_envoronment() method that creates environment from
  provided config
- add template generator for keep legacy behaviour of the
  method describe_environment()
- Environment.define() is deprecated and left for back compatibility
  with older fuel-qa branches
- Some objects in template require the extended database schema,
  so in this patch there are some workarounds to use templates with
  original schema (particular data from address_pools and
  l2_network_devices are stored in the Network model)

[1] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240170/

Change-Id: Iad081bee94c4d3b404eda57b7c1c31011b837ba7
Implements: blueprint template-based-testcases
"}, {'created': '2015-11-11 14:35:06.000000000', 'message': "Move to template-based configuration of devops environments

To create a devops virtual environment (networks, volumes, nodes),
now can be used YAML template desctibed in [1].

How it can be used:

* New approach, environment will be created using the data from
  full_config object:

  environment.create_environment(full_config)

* Old-style approach (deprecated), in this case at first will be
  created a 'full_config' object using shell environment variables,
  and then called environment.create_environment(full_config):

  environment.describe_environment(boot_from='cdrom'):

* Override old-style approach, in this case the YAML config will
  be read from the file located in DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE shell
  environment variable to the 'full_config' object and passed to
  create_environment(full_config); creating config in old-style
  will be skipped:

  export DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE=/tmp/some_template_file.yaml

- add create_envoronment() method that creates environment from
  provided config. There is performed define() and describe()
  actions for each object, so calling environment.describe() is not
  required later.
- add template generator for keep legacy behaviour of the
  method describe_environment()
- Environment.define() is deprecated and left for back compatibility
  with older fuel-qa branches
- Some objects in template require the extended database schema,
  so in this patch there are some workarounds to use templates with
  original schema (particular data from address_pools and
  l2_network_devices are stored in the Network model)

[1] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240170/

Change-Id: Iad081bee94c4d3b404eda57b7c1c31011b837ba7
Implements: blueprint template-based-testcases
"}, {'created': '2015-11-12 17:03:48.000000000', 'message': "Move to template-based configuration of devops environments

To create a devops virtual environment (networks, volumes, nodes),
now can be used YAML template desctibed in [1].

How it can be used:

* New approach, environment will be created using the data from
  full_config object:

  environment.create_environment(full_config)

* Old-style approach (deprecated), in this case at first will be
  created a 'full_config' object using shell environment variables,
  and then called environment.create_environment(full_config):

  environment.describe_environment(boot_from='cdrom'):

* Override old-style approach, in this case the YAML config will
  be read from the file located in DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE shell
  environment variable to the 'full_config' object and passed to
  create_environment(full_config); creating config in old-style
  will be skipped:

  export DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE=/tmp/some_template_file.yaml

- add create_envoronment() method that creates environment from
  provided config.
- environment.describe() method is temporary disabled until new
  database schema be implemented, where all necessary details could
  be passed from define() to desctibe() via database objects.
- add template generator for keep legacy behaviour of the
  method describe_environment()
- Environment.define() is deprecated and left for back compatibility
  with older fuel-qa branches
- Some objects in template require the extended database schema,
  so in this patch there are some workarounds to use templates with
  original schema (particular data from address_pools and
  l2_network_devices are stored in the Network model)

[1] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240170/

Change-Id: Iad081bee94c4d3b404eda57b7c1c31011b837ba7
Implements: blueprint template-based-testcases

  method describe_environment()

  with older fuel-qa branches
- Some objects in template require the extended database schema,
  so in this patch there are some workarounds to use templates with
  original schema (particular data from address_pools and
  l2_network_devices are stored in the Network model)

[1] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240170/

commit_message:
Move to template-based configuration of devops environments

To create a devops virtual environment (networks, volumes, nodes),
now can be used YAML template desctibed in [1].

How it can be used:

* New approach, environment will be created using the data from
  full_config object:

  environment.create_environment(full_config)

* Old-style approach (deprecated), in this case at first will be
  created a 'full_config' object using shell environment variables,
  and then called environment.create_environment(full_config):

  environment.describe_environment(boot_from='cdrom'):

* Override old-style approach, in this case the YAML config will
  be read from the file located in DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE shell
  environment variable to the 'full_config' object and passed to
  create_environment(full_config); creating config in old-style
  will be skipped:

  export DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE=/tmp/some_template_file.yaml

- add create_envoronment() method that creates environment from
  provided config.
- environment.describe() method is temporary disabled until new
  database schema be implemented, where all necessary details could
  be passed from define() to desctibe() via database objects.
- add template generator for keep legacy behaviour of the
  method describe_environment()
- Environment.define() is deprecated and left for back compatibility
  with older fuel-qa branches
- Some objects in template require the extended database schema,
  so in this patch there are some workarounds to use templates with
  original schema (particular data from address_pools and
  l2_network_devices are stored in the Network model)

[1] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240170/

Change-Id: Iad081bee94c4d3b404eda57b7c1c31011b837ba7
Implements: blueprint template-based-virtual-devops-environments

[{'created': '2015-11-24 00:52:35.000000000', 'message': "Fix bootstrap for services

The bootstrap tasks could be started on any node listed in the
site.yml

The issue is that all the tasks must run on the same node, and the
only node that all the tasks can run on is the 'api' node due to
needing to start the bootstrap container which binds in the configs.

delegate_to is required to ensure that the proper node gets the task.

Co-Authored-By: Sam Yaple <sam@yaple.net>
Change-Id: Ica04ab366777a571a92212ac22c482f1881d4ecd
Closes-Bug: #1513598
Related-Bug: #1513439
(cherry picked from commit 790bf336d5e082c5c079bfb681f9509188eae72f)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix bootstrap for services

The bootstrap tasks could be started on any node listed in the
site.yml

The issue is that all the tasks must run on the same node, and the
only node that all the tasks can run on is the 'api' node due to
needing to start the bootstrap container which binds in the configs.

delegate_to is required to ensure that the proper node gets the task.

Co-Authored-By: Sam Yaple <sam@yaple.net>
Change-Id: Ica04ab366777a571a92212ac22c482f1881d4ecd
Closes-Bug: #1513598
Related-Bug: #1513439
(cherry picked from commit 790bf336d5e082c5c079bfb681f9509188eae72f)

subject: Move imageutils from oslo-incubator to cinder namespace

Move imageutils from oslo-incubator to cinder namespace

Change-Id: Iee92d932f04fe7510d4ba724b70cb772c8074262
Closes-Bug: #1517861

[{'account_id': 16425, 'date': '2015-11-06 08:34:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2015-11-06 08:34:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-11-06 09:49:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

(2 comments)

Good start in fixing POST-filtering.

Could you please make GET-filtering to work together with pagination, its arguments are also passed via GET. Currently on second page GET-filter is dropped. To check pagination easily, reduce number of objects per page in Settings to 1. You might want to discuss this change with Justin Pomeroy who implemented server-side filtration in Horizon.

The other consideration is a opinionated one, it seems to me that filter field would provide a better UX if it contained current filtering value (i.e. you type 'Instance1' in this field, press 'Filter' button - the page reloads showing only instances with 'Instance1' in name, but the filter field is now empty - perhaps it would be better for it to still have 'Instance1' inside)."}, {'account_id': 8040, 'date': '2014-10-15 12:55:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Plus, once you get it done right, you'll also need some unit-tests that prove that new filters work ok with pagination."}, {'account_id': 9647, 'date': '2014-10-15 16:17:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

Overall I like this approach, and it does feel better to use a GET for filtering.

We got around the "impossible to filter data on redirect to the table" problem by saving it to the session. If we go this route I think you would want to remove those parts of the code that save the filter into the session and compare the current filter to the one in the session. Basically I don't think this uses the session at all. There is some code in horizon.tables.views (get_server_filter_info, handle_server_filter, update_server_filter_action) that should probably be cleaned up. Not using the session means that the filter goes away if you navigate away from the page and come back, but that is a feature that could be open to debate.

As Timur mentioned this would need to work with pagination, and also make sure it redirects correctly when applying a filter on anything other than the first page.'}, {'account_id': 13325, 'date': '2014-10-21 16:08:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 13325, 'date': '2014-10-21 16:08:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-10-22 00:40:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

(4 comments)

I like this change.

Conferring with UX (Jeff C), we need to keep the URLs simple. With POST, it didn't matter if the keys/vals were ugly, but with GET, it makes the URL unreadable:

http://127.0.0.1:8001/admin/instances/?instances__filter_admin_instances__q_field=name&
instances__filter_admin_instances__q=myinst

I suggest instead:

http://127.0.0.1:8001/admin/instances/?filter_field=name&
filter=myinst

This requires 4 minor changes to the code, which I indicated. I could also go with filter_field and filter_value, or something like that.

If there's some reason why this is a bad idea, then I'll be glad to +1 the code."}, {'account_id': 11902, 'date': '2014-12-02 02:34:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

Another thought: why not change the window title to indicate the filter? If I look at my current history after filtering a bit, I see "Instances - OpenStack Dashboard" about 10 times, which makes the history nearly useless. Instead, how about something like: "Instances - name=myinst - OpenStack Daskboard". That would make a better history entry and bookmark. Maybe it should be in another patch if not trivial; I haven't considered implementation.'}, {'account_id': 13325, 'date': '2014-12-22 11:36:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 13325, 'date': '2014-12-22 11:50:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

@Randy Bertram	
I agree with your suggestions about simplifying url. I've felt that something wrong with it, but can't understand what's exactly is not good. So I've implemented yours suggestion. Now it's much prettier, thank you!
But also I think that despite I understand your desire to make this change, I'm afraid that changing window title is too early."}, {'account_id': 13325, 'date': '2014-12-22 11:52:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

@Randy Bertram .. to early because, as far as I found, this is not common UX in Horizon now. So, I think, it would be better to postpone this change for rewriting tables with AngularJS.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-12-22 12:30:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Verified+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-10-14 12:22:52.000000000', 'message': 'Rewrite table filtering to use GET-requests

Before this patch server table filtering was built on
POST requests, wich is conceptually wrong and makes
impossible to filter data on redirect to the table.

This patch rewrites server table filtering to use
GET request by changing methods get_filter_string() and
get_filter_field().
Also this patch adds some js-code to handle actions in
the filter form.
Now url can contain filtering information, which makes
possible to redirect user to filtered table.
This patchset contains implementation only for table
project/instances to facilitate understanding of the
proposed approach.

Change-Id: I4910295e5fe17ba15f0d8b873131da795747ee80
Closes-Bug: #1368338

commit_message:
Rewrite table filtering to use GET-requests

Before this patch server table filtering was built on
POST requests, wich is conceptually wrong and makes
impossible to filter data on redirect to the table.

This patch rewrites server table filtering to use
GET request by changing methods get_filter_string() and
get_filter_field().
Also this patch adds some js-code to handle actions in
the filter form.
Now url can contain filtering information, which makes
possible to redirect user to filtered table.

Change-Id: I4910295e5fe17ba15f0d8b873131da795747ee80
Closes-Bug: #1368338
Co-Authored-By: Timur Sufiev <tsufiev@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
fix some test case wrongly skipped for mysql backend

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/235831/ enables all test cases for
ysql when PyMySQL is used as MySQL driver, but some test cases are
specified via run_with() decorator, which might expect engine is mysql
while actually we provide mysql+pymysql, so these test cases will be
wrongly skipped.

This patch maps mysql+pymysql to mysql to make sure there is an engine
handles it for such case.

Change-Id: I062d1d04b4b1511626a9b02f0249b5c93b5592b8
Closes-Bug: #1519211

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-20 05:28:42.000000000', 'message': "Fix CONF.set_override usage

As mentioned in the following mail thread [1], when using CONF.set_override,
we'd better explicitly specify 'enforce_type=True', or else there is a
risk that what we are testing is not what users will be using. While the
oslo.config project may fix this param to be default to True, each
project using this call is encouraged to set it.

[1]
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-November/079633.html

Change-Id: I09f9e667cc01b6cb4b7fb5003527608a44f9a6bc
"}]
commit_message:
Fix CONF.set_override usage

As mentioned in the following mail thread [1], when using CONF.set_override,
we'd better explicitly specify 'enforce_type=True', or else there is a
risk that what we are testing is not what users will be using. While the
oslo.config project may fix this param to be default to True, each
project using this call is encouraged to set it.

[1]
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-November/079633.html

Change-Id: I09f9e667cc01b6cb4b7fb5003527608a44f9a6bc

as we won't have ethX scheme anymore"}, {'account_id': 8882, 'date': '2015-11-24 09:30:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

Serge, there is just example for interfaces names in devops env, instead of product. Our names shema in debvops is the same as early.'}, {'account_id': 11081, 'date': '2015-11-24 09:33:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 15943, 'date': '2015-11-24 09:34:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 19119, 'date': '2015-11-24 09:38:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11969, 'date': '2015-11-24 09:55:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19:

Sergii, it's not interface names, it's labels for interface 1, interface 2 and so on/

Templates that should support new interface schema - could use different labels.

Templates that should support old interface schema - could use ethX labels."}, {'account_id': 16106, 'date': '2015-11-24 09:58:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 12275, 'date': '2015-11-24 10:10:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19: Code-Review-1

I have some notes:
1. Please avoid using ethX interface names. Predictable interface naming schema is comming up. (-1 for that).
2. Additional kernel parameters which could be passed to the node will be extremely useful. As example, passing biosdevname=0 net.ifnames=0 to the kernel will switch off predictable interface naming.
3. It's nice to have ability choose a bootstrap image for a particular node. In future we may have a few bootstraps (even for the same OS)."}, {'account_id': 6719, 'date': '2015-11-24 10:18:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

Have some notice for you guys, actually fuel-devops can be run outside of fuel, and actually this spec tell about this, so user can create template, name interfaces like eth, test whatever and start vms with ubuntu, or centos or fedora whatever he/she wants. So the question for you guys, why do you set -1 with comments like bootstrap or eth naming feature that are specific for fuel only and not related to vm start on trusty ubuntu image?'}, {'account_id': 11587, 'date': '2015-11-24 10:24:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 15984, 'date': '2015-11-24 10:35:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 12867, 'date': '2015-11-24 10:36:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11969, 'date': '2015-11-24 11:09:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 19119, 'date': '2015-11-24 11:13:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8882, 'date': '2015-11-24 11:14:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 12275, 'date': '2015-11-24 11:16:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20: Code-Review+1

Actually any interface names are acceptable. Adding a variable enabling passing kernel parameters to kernel (it doesn't meter to bootstrap or to kernel during boot) is up to you. As well as a bootstrap image."}, {'account_id': 17214, 'date': '2015-11-24 11:17:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11969, 'date': '2015-11-24 11:18:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20:

Kernel parameters are not connected to hardware schema. It is related to a particular operation system.

Any additional options related to a specific images could be implemented with Node object model extension:

- choose a 'role' name that you like;
- extend the Node model for this 'role' to get additional options from 'params' and perform necessary actions."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-11-24 11:18:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Verified+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-18 10:25:33.000000000', 'message': "Fix string conversion in s3 handler for python 2

creds_ref['secret'] in s3/ec2 controller has type unicode.
and result type of six.b('AWS4' + secret) is an unicode.
but hmac.new decoder can't work with unicode strings - it
needs 'str' type in python 2.
So here simple change is needed - encode result string as 'utf-8'.
Same conversion we have in signature v1 checking.

Also two comments from previous review was fixed.

Change-Id: I80d862956eace35753f00459d49150a62f07101a
Related-Bug: #1473042
"}]
commit_message:
Fix string conversion in s3 handler for python 2

creds_ref['secret'] in s3/ec2 controller has type unicode.
and result type of six.b('AWS4' + secret) is an unicode.
but hmac.new decoder can't work with unicode strings - it
needs 'str' type in python 2.
So here simple change is needed - encode result string as 'utf-8'.
Same conversion we have in signature v1 checking.

Also two comments from previous review was fixed.

Change-Id: I80d862956eace35753f00459d49150a62f07101a
Related-Bug: #1473042

[{'created': '2015-11-23 05:28:04.000000000', 'message': 'Add parameter sanitization for policy-attach

This patch adds logic to sanitize the parameters provided to a
policy-attach call. The parameter types and values are validated. If
any of the validations fail, a webob.HTTPBadRequest is thrown.

Change-Id: I4a081de911cf0fd2cf8ded1ab1b8c0e0f7b83c7a
Closes-Bug: #1465509

commit_message:
Add parameter sanitization for policy-attach

This patch adds logic to sanitize the parameters provided to a
policy-attach call. The parameter types and values are validated. If
any of the validations fail, a webob.HTTPBadRequest is thrown.

Change-Id: I4a081de911cf0fd2cf8ded1ab1b8c0e0f7b83c7a
Closes-Bug: #1465509

commit_message:
Fix MagnumClientPluginTests

This patch changes MagnumClientPluginTests.test_create to use
'endpoint_override' in place of 'endpoint'.

Change-Id: I90849176bfcea4ae6ec243e71fef5a9b7bca5f3f
Closes-Bug: #1519287

commit_message:
Remove httplib2 useless requirement

This patch cleans up the requirement list to remove httplib2 module
that is not used anymore directly by manila.

Change-Id: I25a1267468f2c6f7e9e18b780ccb09a1d1c41a0a

[{'created': '2015-07-01 14:14:49.000000000', 'message': 'Replace parse_strtime() with parse_isotime()

* Replace parse_strtime(ts) with parse_isotime(ts)
* Replace parse_strtime(ts, fmt) with
  datetime.datetime.strptime(ts, fmt)
* simple_tenant_usage.py: replace the loop trying 3 different timestamp
  format with parse_strtime() with parse_isotime(), parse_isotime()
  already supports the 3 tested formats (and more)
* test_apirequest.py: use directly the datetime.datetime() constructor
  instead of parsing a string
* test_cells_messaging.py: mock parse_isotime() using mock.patch instead
  of mocking it using mox (mock API is simpler than mox API)

oslo_utils.timeutils.parse_isotime() is a superset of parse_strtime().
parse_isotime() accepts timestamps without microseconds and timestamps
with timezone, whereas parse_strtime() requires a timestamp formatted by
strtime() (with microseconds and without any timezone information).

parse_isotime() always create "aware" datetime objects: with a timezone
information. If the timestamp has no timezone information, the UTC
timezone is used by default.

This change is required to prepare nova to replace
oslo_utils.timeutils.strtime(), function deprecated in oslo.utils 1.6.
It is suggested to replace strtime(ts) with ts.isoformat().
parse_strtime() raises an error on timestamp without microsecond,
whereas the .isoformat() method omits microseconds in the output (the
".000000" suffix) if the microsecond attribute is equal to zero:

    >>> timeutils.strtime(datetime.datetime(2015, 7, 1, 10, 24, 22))
    '2015-07-01T10:24:22.000000'
    >>> datetime.datetime(2015, 7, 1, 10, 24, 22).isoformat()
    '2015-07-01T10:24:22'

Change-Id: I591b55be2a7552c5da6f2a0bcd758023210f67d6

commit_message:
Replace parse_strtime() with parse_isotime()

* Replace parse_strtime(ts) with parse_isotime(ts)
* Replace parse_strtime(ts, fmt) with
  datetime.datetime.strptime(ts, fmt)
* simple_tenant_usage.py: replace the loop trying 3 different timestamp
  format with parse_strtime() with parse_isotime(), parse_isotime()
  already supports the 3 tested formats (and more)
* test_apirequest.py: use directly the datetime.datetime() constructor
  instead of parsing a string
* test_cells_messaging.py: mock parse_isotime() using mock.patch instead
  of mocking it using mox (mock API is simpler than mox API)
* db/sqlalchemy/api.py: since parse_strtime() is replaced with
  parse_isotime(), there is no need to fallback on parse_isotime() on
  error

oslo_utils.timeutils.parse_isotime() is a superset of parse_strtime().
parse_isotime() accepts timestamps without microseconds and timestamps
with timezone, whereas parse_strtime() requires a timestamp formatted by
strtime() (with microseconds and without any timezone information).

parse_isotime() always create "aware" datetime objects: with a timezone
information. If the timestamp has no timezone information, the UTC
timezone is used by default.

This change is required to prepare nova to replace
oslo_utils.timeutils.strtime(), function deprecated in oslo.utils 1.6.
It is suggested to replace strtime(ts) with ts.isoformat().
parse_strtime() raises an error on timestamp without microsecond,
whereas the .isoformat() method omits microseconds in the output (the
".000000" suffix) if the microsecond attribute is equal to zero:

    >>> timeutils.strtime(datetime.datetime(2015, 7, 1, 10, 24, 22))
    '2015-07-01T10:24:22.000000'
    >>> datetime.datetime(2015, 7, 1, 10, 24, 22).isoformat()
    '2015-07-01T10:24:22'

blueprint liberty-olso-sync

Change-Id: I591b55be2a7552c5da6f2a0bcd758023210f67d6

Thanks for the fix!
I think that the recommended way is to use the plugin.
However, I would change bootstrap/sync/etc/modprobe.d/mlnx4_core.conf to bootstrap/sync/etc/modprobe.d/mlx4_core.conf since we use this file name for mlx4_core options in the plugin ( https://github.com/openstack/fuel-plugin-mellanox/blob/9839f9f935454c53e543d7963212e0d3fd21a01d/deployment_scripts/sriov.sh#L84-L97 ) in order to avoid kmod conf duplications when using the plugin over IBP..'}, {'account_id': 14200, 'date': '2015-11-16 06:21:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Hi Aviram, it is bad idea to use configuration file from the plugin, because it overwritten during installation as you can see in the same code you're provided: https://github.com/openstack/fuel-plugin-mellanox/blob/9839f9f935454c53e543d7963212e0d3fd21a01d/deployment_scripts/sriov.sh#L97
Also, as you can see i didn't create new file, i use default configuration file already which already exists in the bootstrap."}, {'account_id': 13948, 'date': '2015-11-16 08:05:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2015-11-16 08:09:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11968, 'date': '2015-11-17 09:47:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Changing my vote since this patch was already tested.

Few notes:
1. In CentOS installation the mlx4_core.conf file will be overwritten by our plugin, and MLNX_OFED manage the services/modules anyway.
2. The bootstrap file name was changed (mlx to mlnx, I think that mistakenly) when moved to sync dir https://github.com/openstack/fuel-main/commit/9ccf7fda00bea911d9458739bd8ac6982469f478 .
Moreover, the hook of modprobing mlx4_en is exists in libmlx4 inbox package, that should be installed in the bootstrap - https://github.com/openstack/fuel-main/blob/stable/6.1/bootstrap/module.mk#L200.
3. The only certified and tested way of using Mellanox HW and features is by installing the plugin.'}, {'account_id': 14200, 'date': '2015-11-20 10:20:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 14200, 'date': '2015-11-23 08:16:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-11-23 08:16:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

commit_message:
Mellanox ethernet driver (mlx4_en) autoloading together with core driver

Mellanox ethernet driver (mlx4_en) should be loaded together together with
core driver (mlx4_core).

This fix for default CentOS provision image taken from the libmlx4 package.

Change-Id: Ic1c26ff610fc657d05a854e81cf3681f3eeb0c45
Closes-Bug: #1501309

commit_message:
Quota Policy Engine

There are many different ways that deployers may want to slice
their private cloud - availability zones, aggregates exposed
via flavors and special flavors being the most common amongst
all the available options. There are different ways to impose
quota based on the slice mechanism used. Quota policy engine
provide a way to validate whether a particular quota operation
is valid or not depending on the actual resource consumption
and what is requested by the incoming request.

Change-Id: I88c73d051e324bebe46d6f9df6067fa9330e70a8
Implements: blueprint quota-policy-engine

subject: Quota by Flavor, Quota by AZ or Quota by (Flavor and AZ)

- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/60/206160/4/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/b6fc176/ : SUCCESS in 1m 42s'}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2015-07-28 03:27:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

As an operator, this is definitely a feature that I would like to see added.

However, I don't like the suggested way of using dynamic quotas, specifically what is shown as an example in Step 8.

I don't think the user should have to enter any additional information in order to use dynamic quotas. A user shouldn't have to worry about quota implementation at all -- they should only care about the amount of resources they have available to use and what has been used.

Perhaps a better implementation would be to tie the dynamic quota tag/keyword into the flavor?

Continuing with the SSD example, a host aggregate of SSD-based compute nodes would be created and a flavor with metadata would also be created allowing instances to be launched on that node. Either that same piece of metadata or another piece of metadata could then be tied to the flavor that increments the number of instances that the user has launched on the SSD nodes.

Also, this spec explicitly mentions that the dynamic quota will be decremented by 1. IMO, this is OK and I can see myself still doing a lot with dynamic quotas that only decrease or increase by 1. However, having the ability to decrement/increment by more than 1 is something else that may be useful."}, {'account_id': 7455, 'date': '2015-07-28 04:04:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi Joe,

Thanks a lot for your input.
We did think about tagging the flavor with quota resource. 
But, it will lead to bloating of flavors.

Let's say the cloud offers 5 standard flavors.
And we have SSD hardware for each type of flavor.
In that case, we will have to create 5 more flavors and tag them with SSD quota resource for allowing the user to boot an instance with SSD flavor.

Also, lets say we want to create a quota resource per availability zone - PDU1.
But, PDU1 does have capability to boot all 5 flavors.
So, we will have to create 5 more flavors and tag them with PDU1 quota resource.

To summarize, 
if we want to assign quota for X resources
and we have Y standard flavors,
we will have to expose X * Y flavors to users.

Also, either flavor name needs to reflect what quota resource is tagged to it.
Or user needs to run nova flavor-show to select appropriate flavor.
In some way or the other user needs to know what kind of flavor he is selecting.

So, we thought that instead of an user selecting flavor based on appropriate tags/name, let an user pass a standard flavor as he would.
In addition to flavor, he would do a nova quota-show and pass the resource name to --dynamic-quota-resource param during nova boot. 

Does that make sense ?"}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2015-07-28 04:48:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Thanks for your reply :)

To use your specific examples, creating an "ssd" series of flavors is exactly what we would do. To continue picking on the SSD example, SSD disks are (usually) of less capacity than spindle disks. We would most definitely want custom flavors that consume less ephemeral disk because of that. In addition, since SSD disks have a great IO capability, we'd want to set different libvirt IO limits on the flavor, too.

The example of only allowing x instances to use a certain PDU: I totally agree that to have this on a flavor is a bit silly. But wouldn't it make more sense to be able to tag the host aggregate / AZ with the dynamic quota instead of requiring the user to specify some arbitrary tag themselves?

IMO, OpenStack has several different ways to slice up a cloud. What's lacking is the ability to restrict custom amounts of resource consumption based on those slices. I see the proper implementation as augmenting these existing means of slices rather than placing the responsibility on the user -- in effect, a lot of times they'll end up specifying the same information twice:

* I must choose an SSD based flavor that allows for higher IO *and* I must specify a dynamic quota tag that will decrement this from my quota.
* I must choose an AZ to use a certain PDU *and* I must specify a dynamic quota tag that will decrement this from my quota.

Even typing that out sounds like it's something that should be done internal to OpenStack and not exposed to the user.'}, {'account_id': 7455, 'date': '2015-07-28 15:46:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I see your point.

Let's say we want to assign quota per flavor X. In that case, we create a resource called flavor_x, update extra specs for flavor X with resource id. And we will be able to obtain dynamic quota resource from extra spec during instance creation.
For, quota per flavor, obtaining resource-id from flavor extra specs is straightforward.

If we look at existing means to slice the cloud, they are:
1. create aggregates and expose them via flavors
2. create availability zones (AZs)

(1) is taken care of by adding resource-id to flavor extra specs. If we are creating aggregates, we will have to expose them via flavors. So, if we want to assign quota per aggregate (SSD hw for example), we could update flavor extra specs to include aggregate specific quota resource id.

For (2), an AZ is not exposed via flavors. So, we will have to use underlying aggregate's metadata to store resource-id. 

To summarize, we will be obtaining quota resource-id from:
1. Flavor extra specs
2. Aggregate's metadata

Now, we will have to decide which resource-id to give precedence, if both flavor and AZ containing resource-id (via aggregate's metadata) is passed. Which one should we pick in that case ?"}, {'account_id': 7455, 'date': '2015-07-29 00:32:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7455, 'date': '2015-07-29 00:33:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 7455, 'date': '2015-07-29 00:34:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 7455, 'date': '2015-07-29 00:47:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Joe - Vilobh and I discussed your comments and we agreed that there are two means to slice the cloud - 
1. Create aggregates and expose them via flavors.
2. Create availability zones.
So, we should only focus on assigning quota for current means rather than focus on creating any arbitrary quota resource independent of flavor or AZ.

Also, if we focus on allowing dynamic quota resource only for a combination of flavor and AZ, then openstack should be able to identify dynamic quota resource on flavor and availability zone passed during instance creation. 

With this, user does not have to pass an explicit dynamic quota resource id.
Also, we do not need to store resource-id in flavor extra specs or aggregate metadata.

Have updated the spec accordingly.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-07-29 01:09:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2015-07-29 01:11:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Hi Meghal,

That's awesome! I just re-read the spec and, from my point of view, the implementation sounds more intuitive. 

Thank you very much for being so receptive to the feedback."}, {'account_id': 7455, 'date': '2015-07-29 01:11:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-07-29 03:14:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Verified-1

It sounds like you want multiple quotas rather than dynamic quota resources? Say I have quota for 20 cores and 1 SSD. If I put all 20 cores into my single SSD box, that consumes far more SSD hw than if I put 18 cores into standard VMs and 2 into an SSD VM. I don't think this feature is useful for the stated purpose.

Have you seen bp quotas_reimagined and bp resource-objects? I'd expect Nova team to want to fix quotas as they stand before adding features, AIUI quotas desync frequently right now making them pretty broken."}, {'account_id': 10263, 'date': '2015-07-29 17:26:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 10263, 'date': '2015-07-29 17:44:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Thanks Alexis for the review. Please see my reply inline.

A] It sounds like you want multiple quotas rather than dynamic quota resources? 

[Vilobh] No we want dynamic quota resources and not multiple quotas. Depending on the number of dynamic quota resource we will have quota details for those many resource as its done even today. So in short number of entries for resource hard_limit in nova.quotas = number of dynamic quota resources. If thats what you mean by "multiple quotas" then yes if not then just the first sentence should hold true.

B] Say I have quota for 20 cores and 1 SSD. If I put all 20 cores into my single SSD box, that consumes far more SSD hw than if I put 18 cores into standard VMs and 2 into an SSD VM. I don't think this feature is useful for the stated purpose.

It is consider both approaches :-
A] If you put all 20 cores into my single SSD box :-

[Vilobh] Lets say you create an aggregate for this, or any logical grouping for this stuff, this basically boils down to the problem of Quota by Flavor and we don't need to do something specific here as Flavor will be composed of basic static resources like core, ram, disk and if any provided by the extra specs.

B] If you put 18 cores into standard VMs and 2 into an SSD VM :-

[Vilobh] In that case your can track Quota by Flavor for standard VM's created on HDD(say) and Quota by Flavor for SSD VM's both these Quotas for number of resources used will be disjoint. Think of dynamic quota resource as a group ; a specialized group (in your case SSD); where we would like to track quota.

C] Have you seen bp quotas_reimagined and bp resource-objects? I'd expect Nova team to want to fix quotas as they stand before adding features, AIUI quotas desync frequently right now making them pretty broken.

[Vilobh] bp quotas_reimagined - proposes to add quota object for each resource rather than being tracked by a single entry in DB. This can be an enhancement but not a preliminary requirement for this spec IMHO. As many admin's have been asking for a feature like "Quota by "X"". I have updated the same in patch set #9.

bp resource-objects : can also help.

I agree that we need a way to make quota usages more better and bp quotas_reimagined, bp resource-objects can help there but again I think of them as an enhancement and not a preliminary requirement of this spec.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-07-29 20:44:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Verified+1

- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/60/206160/9/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/3ffad11/ : SUCCESS in 2m 38s'}, {'account_id': 8688, 'date': '2015-07-31 10:06:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(14 comments)

I've added some line comments on specifics, while we talk about generalities out here.


A] It sounds like you want multiple quotas rather than dynamic quota resources?
[Vilobh] No we want dynamic quota resources and not multiple quotas. Depending on the number of dynamic quota resource we will have quota details for those many resource as its done even today. So in short number of entries for resource hard_limit in nova.quotas = number of dynamic quota resources. If thats what you mean by "multiple quotas" then yes if not then just the first sentence should hold true.

[lxs] That didn't make any sense to me. I have learnt from reading the spec that your dynamic quota resources seem to be exclusively concerned with flavors and AZs. For example there's no way (that I can see) to put a quota on an aggregate in your proposed system. So maybe you meant to say, that flavor-quotas already constrain the amount of cores and RAM allocated by virtue of the flavor being fixed?

This does lead to a bin-packing problem when you try to assert an overall cap on a resource like SSD. It can help to carefully design your flavors to pack neatly but that can lead to wasted hardware.

B] Say I have quota for 20 cores and 1 SSD. If I put all 20 cores into my single SSD box, that consumes far more SSD hw than if I put 18 cores into standard VMs and 2 into an SSD VM. I don't think this feature is useful for the stated purpose.

[lxs] Bearing in mind the above, this question didn't really make sense. Sorry.

[Vilobh] I agree that we need a way to make quota usages more better and bp quotas_reimagined, bp resource-objects can help there but again I think of them as an enhancement and not a preliminary requirement of this spec.

[lxs] My experience of Nova team is that they like to get the foundations solid before building the towers. I'm just trying to set your expectations a little. There is a lot of work being proposed in this area already and it's foundational rather than new features, so I wouldn't count on this merging any time soon. That said, I'm not core so I could easily be wrong. And there's no harm in asking for comments.'}, {'account_id': 9452, 'date': '2015-07-31 18:36:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2015-07-31 22:57:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)

Comments inline. Overall I think this has a lot of detail and not enough high-level explanation ahead of the detail. It's also not clear to me how a cloud admin is supposed to define a dynamic resource, how they will add a new resource, and how users will discover dynamic resources and use them."}, {'account_id': 7455, 'date': '2015-08-05 20:27:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(20 comments)

Vilobh and I have discussed details about how an admin will be updating dynamic quota resource. He will update the spec accordingly.

I have replied to rest of the comments from Alexis and Melanie.
Thanks for your inputs.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-08-05 23:29:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(3 comments)

Hi Meghan, we're mostly in APAC so arranging a time might be tricky. I've tried to describe my idea in more detail, please let me know what you think."}, {'account_id': 8688, 'date': '2015-08-21 13:59:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8688, 'date': '2015-08-21 14:40:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

So I talked with alaski on IRC. He and johnthetubaguy would both like to see "a more powerful quota engine what operates much like the policy engine, [which lets] operators define what they want to track against a quota and define arbitrary quotas".

We discussed the ideas of "flavor classes" (EG "standard" and "ssd", each containing small, medium and large variants) and "tenant groups" (eg the "gold" tenant group would have certain quotas). Both of these normalise the model, reducing the combinatorial explosion that can happen.

Finally alaski suggested to get this onto the agenda for discussion at the Tokyo summit.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2015-08-21 21:23:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(3 comments)

To add to what Alexis said: I have concerns about continuing to add more hardcoded ways of defining quotas because as the spec mentions there are many different ways that deployers may want to slice things.  What I would prefer is a generic language that can be used to define quota checks to make, similar to the policy checks we have today.  A horrible off the top of my head example would be something like "tenant_group:gold and az:1": "(RAM:200 and disk:500) or flavor:3:10"'}, {'account_id': 10263, 'date': '2015-08-21 21:32:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

@Alaski, Alexis :

Agree that would be an ideal route but nothing of that sort exist in its current state of art we thought of taking this route, although during our brainstorming session we did think about the idea of using a generic policy engine as you have bought up here, when we have these quota_classes, flavor_classes, tenant_groups etc. Is there a spec or blueprint for the same ?'}, {'account_id': 13997, 'date': '2015-08-27 11:25:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

Meghal, thanks for the patch. Some minor comments inline.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2015-08-27 13:30:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

Vilobh: There is no current spec or blueprint for quota policy handling that I am aware of.  What I would prefer is if work started in that direction rather than adding another hardcoded quota rule.  But I am only one voice which is why I suggest bringing this topic to the summit if possible and gathering feedback on it there.'}, {'account_id': 17172, 'date': '2015-10-15 05:54:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-10-15 13:57:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

So totally agree we need to solve your problem here.

But there are some blockers for me right now...

1)
Really need to fix quotas before we add complexity.

2)
I don't like the model you propose here, it does seem quite right

So lets look at quota_instances. What you are wanting to do here is add a "scope" to that quota. In theory we might want to scope any of the instance quotas (like cores or memory) so a specific set of instances.

If we think to user quotas and nested quotas, its about optionally adding an extra restriction on some subset of users. If we treat scoped quotas in the same way, you have a global value for quota_instances and the scoped value. You should never exceed either of those checks.

We also need to look at default quotas, a little more. We need a way to say, by default all users get zero quota for this specific set of resources, in a way its more like policy.

When you look at the flavor scope, as alaski mentioned, its probably better to think about a group of flavors. You might want to limit the amount of SSD GBs across all SSD based flavors, for example.

So with this all in mind, I think we get something like:

* when adding a quota, there is now an optional "scope", be that for a user, tenant, or by default.
* if the scope is None (unscoped), its a global resource scope (all instances)
* a collection of admin defined named quota_scopes makes sense, right now you can add flavor and availability_zone limits, eventually I hope you can add flavor_class in there, I would prefer that from the beginning, but you can't get everything you want.

When you try a protected action (create instance), then you check all applicable quotas, global quotas and scoped quotas.

i.e. if you have a global quota used up, having some available in another scoped quota makes no difference.

Does this make any sense, and does this sound like it would meet your use case?'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-11-24 10:49:52.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

long time and no response, assuming this is not wanted for mitaka, and marking as abandoned.

Please restore if that is not the case.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-11-24 11:13:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

there is a related spec here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/222824/2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-07-27 17:30:35.000000000', 'message': 'Provide support for creating dynamic quota resources

blueprint dynamic-quota-resource

Change-Id: I13b8e15896ffcb7d3aafe6bffb394ef1c8f487ca
'}, {'created': '2015-07-27 18:34:13.000000000', 'message': 'Quota Management for Dynamic Quota Resources

During creation or deletion of an instance, quota needs to be calculated
and committed or rollbacked accordingly. Currently, quota calculations
are based on 14 static resources hardcoded in the quota module. These
static resources are cores, ram, disk, instances and so on. At present,
there is no support provided for an openstack admin to create dynamic
quota resources and assign quota for a specific project, based on the
newly created dynamic resource. Dynamic resource can be a combination
of availability zone, flavor, hardware type or any key-value pair that
the admin chooses. This spec plans to provide an option to
create and manage the dynamic resource through instance lifecycle and
also provide a way for quota management of these newly introduced
dynamic resources.

Co-Authored-By: Vilobh Meshram <vilobhmm@yahoo-inc.com>
Co-Authored-By: Joshua Harlow <harlowja@yahoo-inc.com>

blueprint dynamic-quota-resource

Change-Id: I13b8e15896ffcb7d3aafe6bffb394ef1c8f487ca
'}, {'created': '2015-07-28 00:26:38.000000000', 'message': 'Quota Management for Dynamic Quota Resources

During creation or deletion of an instance, quota needs to be calculated
and committed or rollbacked accordingly. Currently, quota calculations
are based on 14 static resources hardcoded in the quota module. These
static resources are cores, ram, disk, instances and so on. At present,
there is no support provided for an openstack admin to create dynamic
quota resources and assign quota for a specific project, based on the
newly created dynamic resource. Dynamic resource can be a combination
of availability zone, flavor, hardware type or any random resource key
that the admin chooses. Also, admin can add more metadata (key-value
pairs) to dynamic quota resources. This metadata can be used for
providing more information to the end-user as well as during selection
of hardware. This spec plans to provide an option to create and manage
the dynamic resource through instance lifecycle and
also provide a way for quota management of these newly introduced
dynamic resources.

Co-Authored-By: Vilobh Meshram <vilobhmm@yahoo-inc.com>
Co-Authored-By: Joshua Harlow <harlowja@yahoo-inc.com>

'}, {'created': '2015-08-06 00:31:00.000000000', 'message': 'Quota Management for Dynamic Quota Resources

During creation or deletion of an instance, quota needs to be calculated
and committed or rollbacked accordingly. Currently, quota calculations
are based on 14 static resources hardcoded in the quota module. These
static resources are cores, ram, disk, instances and so on.
There are multiple ways to slice the cloud - availability zones,
aggregates exposed via flavors and special flavors.
But, there is no support provided for an openstack admin to create dynamic
quota resources based on these openstack cloud slices and assign quota to a
specific project, based on the newly created dynamic quota resources.
Dynamic quota resource can be a combination of availability zone, flavor or
hardware type aggregate exposed via a flavor.
This spec plans to provide an option to create and manage the dynamic resource
through instance lifecycle and also provide a way for quota management of
these newly introduced dynamic resources.

Co-Authored-By: Vilobh Meshram <vilobhmm@yahoo-inc.com>
Co-Authored-By: Joshua Harlow <harlowja@yahoo-inc.com>

'}, {'created': '2015-08-07 01:05:11.000000000', 'message': 'Quota by Flavor, Quota by AZ, Quota by X

There are multiple ways to slice an Openstack cloud - availability
zones, aggregates exposed via flavors and special flavors being the
most common amongst all the available options. These options are used
for better operability, managebility and providing specific
features to enhance performance. But even though we have a way to
seggregate the cloud as per these options, there is no option
for properly managing the quota associated with them. At present,
there is no option provided for an Openstack admin to set and manage
Quota by Flavor, Quota by AZ or both.

This spec plans to solve this problem by introducing the concept of
dynamic resource. Dynamic resource can be a combination of
availability zone, flavor or hardware type aggregate exposed
via a flavor which can help for effective quota management in
these comman deployment scenarios.

Co-Authored-By: Vilobh Meshram <vilobhmm@yahoo-inc.com>
Co-Authored-By: Joshua Harlow <harlowja@yahoo-inc.com>

blueprint dynamic-quota-resource

for better operability, managebility and providing specific
features to enhance performance. But even though we have a way to
segregate the cloud as per these options, at present, there is
no option provided for an Openstack admin to set and manage Quota
by Flavor, Quota by AZ or both.

This spec plans to solve this problem by introducing the concept
of dynamic resources. A dynamic resource can be a combination of
availability zone, flavor or hardware type aggregate exposed via
a flavor which can help for effective quota management in these
common deployment scenarios.

Co-Authored-By: Vilobh Meshram <vilobhmm@yahoo-inc.com>
Co-Authored-By: Joshua Harlow <harlowja@yahoo-inc.com>
blueprint dynamic-quota-resource
Change-Id: I13b8e15896ffcb7d3aafe6bffb394ef1c8f487ca
'}]
commit_message:
Quota by Flavor, Quota by AZ or Quota by (Flavor and AZ)

There are multiple ways to slice an Openstack cloud - availability
zones, aggregates exposed via flavors and special flavors being the
most common amongst all the available options. These options are used
for better operability, managebility and providing specific
features to enhance performance. But even though we have a way to
segregate the cloud as per these options, at present, there is
no option provided for an Openstack admin to set and manage Quota
by Flavor, Quota by AZ or both.

This spec plans to solve this problem by introducing the concept
of dynamic resources. A dynamic resource can be a combination of
availability zone, flavor or hardware type aggregate exposed via
a flavor which can help for effective quota management in these
common deployment scenarios.

Co-Authored-By: Vilobh Meshram <vilobhmm@yahoo-inc.com>
Co-Authored-By: Joshua Harlow <harlowja@yahoo-inc.com>
blueprint dynamic-quota-resource
Change-Id: I13b8e15896ffcb7d3aafe6bffb394ef1c8f487ca

commit_message:
Limit the number of instances that a user can spawn in a time window

Rate-limits can limit API calls, but on POST */servers, there is
a possibility to specify max_count and ask large number of instances
in a very short time.
As operator, I want to rate-limit the real instance creation, not
only the API calls.

Change-Id: I49ade2885bab4671474567e72c892de6c2677778

commit_message:
deprecate `enabled` option for endpoint-policy extension

the endpoint-policy extension, like the other recently moved
extensions, should be always enabled. Since this option made
its way into the liberty release we need to mark the option
as deprecated in M and remove it in O

implements bp: move-extensions

Change-Id: I5c01da0663c636bc6e2d9f12ac02b53edb9a277f

commit_message:
Implement Ovs2Ovs patch support CentOS7/RHEL7

*Implement tags for ovs2ovs patch for Centos7/RHEL7
*Implement ovs port for Ubuntu and Centos7/RHEL7
*Test coverage

Change-Id: I553a9d152f83b6a24ab5a5a3e4bb6bf41edbb303
Closes-bug: #1514421

subject: Host maintenance mode
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 136, 'name': 'Tim Bell', 'email': 'tim.bell@cern.ch', 'username': 'tim-bell'}, {'_account_id': 782, 'name': 'John Garbutt', 'email': 'john@johngarbutt.com', 'username': 'johngarbutt'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 6062, 'name': 'jichenjc', 'email': 'jichenjc@cn.ibm.com', 'username': 'jichenjc'}, {'_account_id': 7166, 'name': 'Sylvain Bauza', 'email': 'sbauza@redhat.com', 'username': 'sbauza'}, {'_account_id': 7664, 'name': 'Joe Cropper', 'email': 'jwcroppe@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'jwcroppe'}, {'_account_id': 9708, 'name': 'Balazs Gibizer', 'display_name': 'gibi', 'email': 'gibizer@gmail.com', 'username': 'gibi'}, {'_account_id': 11303, 'name': 'Markus Zoeller (markus_z)', 'email': 'mzoeller@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'mzoeller'}, {'_account_id': 12299, 'name': 'Pawel Koniszewski', 'email': 'pawel.koniszewski@gmail.com', 'username': 'pawel.koniszewski'}, {'_account_id': 14937, 'name': 'Tang Chen', 'email': 'imtangchen@163.com', 'username': 'tangchen'}]

[{'account_id': 14937, 'date': '2015-09-29 02:08:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-09-29 02:13:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/89/228689/1/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/cd59c23//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 06s
- gate-nova-specs-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/89/228689/1/check/gate-nova-specs-pep8/58eaf9e/ : SUCCESS in 1m 57s
- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/89/228689/1/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/ea5bc00/ : SUCCESS in 2m 24s'}, {'account_id': 14937, 'date': '2015-09-29 05:26:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated'}, {'account_id': 14937, 'date': '2015-09-29 05:27:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-09-29 05:33:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/89/228689/3/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/983985b//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 36s
- gate-nova-specs-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/89/228689/3/check/gate-nova-specs-pep8/cd5b050/ : SUCCESS in 1m 50s
- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/89/228689/3/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/a7b479d/ : SUCCESS in 2m 04s'}, {'account_id': 6062, 'date': '2015-10-12 13:55:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14937, 'date': '2015-10-13 01:26:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-10-15 09:31:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Sorry, from your spec I do not understand what you expect host maintenance mode to do.

To be clear, any orchestration to move all the VMs off a compute node, would be strictly out of scope for Nova:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/project_scope.html#no-more-orchestration

From memory, the current XenAPI driver host maintenance mode does not move any virtual machines, for example, it just sets a state inside XenAPI that says the host is in maintenance mode.

We use the disable host flag as a way to tell people a compute node is about to have some maintenance done, although there may be use cases where that doesn't work, its unclear form this spec.

There is already a python-novaclient CLI command to help orchestrate removing all servers from a previously disabled host."}, {'account_id': 11303, 'date': '2015-10-15 12:32:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

How does the call "nova host-update --maintenance enable" differ from the sequential call of "nova service-disable" + "nova host-evacuate-live"? If it doesn't differ, is it a convenience API? If yes, do we care about convenience APIs?

That's the same question I had for https://review.openstack.org/#/c/204157/ I'd rather deprecate the "host-maintenance-mode" REST API, it's a confusing thing and doesn't explain what it does and is right now XEN only.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-10-15 16:19:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

I'm in favor of deprecating this function entirely, not adding it to new virt drivers, and definitely not trying to provide an orchestrated evacuation of a compute host from within nova. The latter certainly violates our no-more-orchestration principle, aside from the fact that we should deprecate this method in general, IMHO."}, {'account_id': 14937, 'date': '2015-10-16 01:50:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi all,

I'm sorry. It's true. My implementation of host maintenance mode is almost the same with disable-service + evacuate-vms. And I have talked about this in IRC. I think it is better to do it in novaclient, and host_maintenance_mode() API on Nova side should simply enable/disable the service.

Will update the BP and spec.

Thanks."}, {'account_id': 14937, 'date': '2015-10-16 03:31:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-10-16 03:35:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/89/228689/4/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/651e3c4//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 3m 24s
- gate-nova-specs-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/89/228689/4/check/gate-nova-specs-pep8/d5f7743/ : SUCCESS in 1m 54s
- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/89/228689/4/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/5363aad/ : SUCCESS in 1m 48s'}, {'account_id': 14937, 'date': '2015-10-16 03:40:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi Dan,

I have updated the spec and propose a new implementation direction. I'm trying to implement it on novaclient side.  Please help to review.

Thanks."}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2015-10-16 08:55:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I'm really not fan of pushing more logic to something already weak in the Nova CLI to be honest.

Some people are wondering why our contrib tools are behaving that way without properly taking care of error handling, but I feel that level of orchestration doesn't have to stay in the CLI."}, {'account_id': 11303, 'date': '2015-10-16 09:20:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

In yesterdays Nova meeting was a call to deprecate the host-maintenance REST API [1]. Would be great if this blueprint would take that direction :)

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova/2015/nova.2015-10-15-14.01.html'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-10-16 10:00:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-2

(1 comment)

This does seem to be the opposite of what was mentioned on the ML.

We want to remove the host maintenance API, it doesn't do anything useful in any driver.

Now if you could please articulate the operational problem you have that needs solving, we can help you find the solution.

If you want to move all VMs off a host, you disable the host (stops any new VMs landing there), then can use the python-novaclient live-migrate all VMs off a host call. That works today on almost all of the Nova drivers.

What bit in the above picture does not work in your use case?"}, {'account_id': 14937, 'date': '2015-10-17 02:50:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi John, Markus, Sylvain,

I think the original reason why we started this work is that "nova host-update --maintenance enable" does't work on a KVM box. And I have to apologize for that I didn't understand correctly that this command is almost the same as disable + evacuate, and the role of Nova and the orchestration thing. 

First of all, I think host maintenance mode is defined as a mode for host to upgrade its OS, software and hardware. That means maybe not only compute, but also other openstack services need to be stopped. Indeed, this needs a lot of checks. 

Now after all this discussion, "nova host-update" does look like a convenience API. 

So, if we don't care about convenience APIs in Nova, and if I want this convenience command, what should I do ?

And also, by deprecating host maintenance mode entirely, you guys mean removing nova client command and REST API, right ?

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-10-19 12:48:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

We already have APIs in python-novaclient to live-migrate all servers in a host.

I suggest we first add better docs on how to use the existing methods, so others can find them more easily.

This spec should then really discuss what problems there are with the existing connivence methods, and why we need a new one, or extend the existing one.

We certainly do not want to call the new method host maintenance mode, its would cause lots of confusion.

Please do catch me in IRC (johnthetubaguy) to discuss this, if that helps.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-11-24 11:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

OK, we seem to have reach consensus to not to this, and make improvements to python-novaclient instead.'}]

commit_message:
Host maintenance mode

Provide a default host maintenance mode handling to enable compute node
machines to upgrade OS or hardware without pausing running instances in
Nova compute, independant to drivers.

Implements: blueprint host-maintenance-mode
Change-Id: Icd4a3e40c8f3aa0af7729a868ebc64f84a7857c9

commit_message:
Live migrate local disk

User is not allowed to execute live-migration of
a booted from volume instance which have a local disk
in non-shared storage environment.
This blueprint make it enable by copying local disk
from the source host to the destination host.

Blueprint: live-migrate-local-disk
Change-Id: I1a44685cbbed7364b8bb8566075f67f481d3a1c4

Looks pretty good, but why is it generated on the keystone nodes? I'm not sure I'm comfortable with extraneous admin creds being pushed out to every control node. Is there a way we can generate it just on the deploy node? (i.e. the node where kolla+init-runonce is installed)"}, {'account_id': 16993, 'date': '2015-11-22 03:46:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 16993, 'date': '2015-11-22 03:47:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi, Paul. I agree; the deploy node is a better place for the openrc file. Please re-check the updated patch set. Thank. - Hui'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-11-22 04:13:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

(1 comment)

Looks great Hui thanks! Very small question on the docs'}, {'account_id': 14119, 'date': '2015-11-23 14:15:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

hello,

We have talked about doing this before, but the one stipulation is that it must _not_ be done inline like this. For security purposes we do not want to create an openrc file like this.

A separate playbook or something similar is fine.

The openrc file can be generated before or after keystone since it is only stitching together the config variables'}, {'account_id': 16993, 'date': '2015-11-23 14:46:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Hi, Sam,
This may not be a security problem because the openrc file is created on the deploy node only. Since the admin user operates on deployment, the openrc file should be visible to him/her. What do you think? Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 14119, 'date': '2015-11-23 14:49:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

No it is definitely a security risk.

Right now you can use ansible's password vault stuff to encrypt the passwords file. With what you are purposing you expose those passwords in plaintext on the deployment node.

Additionally, you now require write permissions to /etc/kolla which the deployment tool has not required in the past"}, {'account_id': 16993, 'date': '2015-11-23 15:40:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sam, thanks for your explanation. So to avoid the security issue, as well as to generate the openrc file automatically, I would like to add a seperate playbook, called post_run.yml and a role "openrc".
The openrc role will generate the admin-openrc in the current directory of kolla other than /etc/kolla. Comment?'}, {'account_id': 14119, 'date': '2015-11-23 16:02:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

It doesnt need its own role for something so simple. A playbook with a single task is fine.

    ---
    - hosts: all
      tasks:
      - copy:
          src: blah/blah.j2
          dest: blah'}, {'account_id': 16993, 'date': '2015-11-23 22:03:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 16993, 'date': '2015-11-23 22:04:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi, Sam, could you re-exam this patch. Not sure where is a good place to put the admin-rc.j2. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-11-23 22:55:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

commit_message:
Create openrc file on the deploy node

This task is run as a post-deploy playbook

Implements: blueprint ansible-task-generate-openrc
Change-Id: I69f4ee895094da5c73494a41dccb2e86eb481656

commit_message:
Simplify role assignment example

You can pass the name of the project, user, and role to the
"openstack role add" command, so the example can be simplified.

Change-Id: I82a5382d4450ff03f5448e1a3792e98b764dfba7

commit_message:
Really skip directories for translation sync

This fixes a problem on stable/liberty for openstack-manuals where only
2 out of 12 directories should be translated. But we currently push all
12 source files to the server.

If we have directories that contain locale files, we need to explicitly
exclude them. Add the skip directories to the exclude list for
manual projects.

Change-Id: I1eb481772545261c293baa0eb35731a8ac92d53c

commit_message:
tripleo.sh initial support for stable branches

Adds STABLE_RELEASE variable, which can be set, e.g to "liberty"
such that we configure the repos to use the centos7-liberty current
repos instead of trunk.

This automates the steps documented in:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/238600/

Change-Id: I34ea635382114bf4f075f3d8df1188c3beae8727
(cherry picked from commit 17209ca9d6a980201dbee90f1699f07baf118aca)

commit_message:
Update the repo whitelist to reflect what we CI

We should only be using the current repository for
packages that we are running ci on. This is the
list of what we CI.

Closes-Bug: #1507378
Change-Id: I14f699ea8b8230907f6fd3a8cef58e483a201f91
(cherry picked from commit 27a311d0e6a5d4f910e393b6afb3a4c332daf0b2)

commit_message:
Disallow profile update for spec

Previously we support creating new profiles when doing profile-update,
if a new 'spec' is provided. However, this looks like an abuse of the
'update' operation. It creates more confusion than convenience. This
patch proposes removing 'spec' from the update interface. More patches
will come to remove this completely. This is only about the API and the
RPC client layer.

Change-Id: Id8edf1d1bcb33f85dbdad614dd4db27285f17d0a

commit_message:
scan all changes and filter on files in reno not git log

Scanning only changes with reno files in them means we miss some of the
git tags in the repository history, so include all patches in the git
log output and then filter them in reno based on patches that include
any release notes files.

Closes-bug: #1517175
Change-Id: I36c0a54e20d47fff9af2b7f82c5380d97345a625

commit_message:
Fix bug introduced by openstacksdk

This patch sets the default auth_plugin to 'password', it also removes
the authenticator reference from client module. These code are breaking
the client code.

Change-Id: I7f815d3847b0bd0f5e6c3f78c2cc0efd3c80a523

commit_message:
remove elasticsearch method delete_by_query

The elasticsearch method delete_by_query has been removed
from the api because deprecated since elasticsearch 1.7

see:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/1.7/docs-delete-by-query.html

Change-Id: Ib21708c7147f4202eb7e4dba7a64adbc192d94af

We don't support Centos based envs and this part of make system is outdated. There is even patch that removes this part  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/248115/. Probably in 9.0 we will support centos as a cluster operating system and then we will need to implement centos image building exactly the same way as for ubuntu, which means building images using fuel agent."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-19 19:59:20.000000000', 'message': 'Mellanox ethernet driver (mlx4_en) autoloading together with core driver

Mellanox ethernet driver (mlx4_en) should be loaded together together with
core driver (mlx4_core).

Fix for CentOS bootstrap image and default CentOS provision image.

Change-Id: Ic1c26ff610fc657d05a854e81cf3681f3eeb0c45
Closes-Bug: #1501309
'}, {'created': '2015-11-20 11:14:29.000000000', 'message': 'Mellanox ethernet driver (mlx4_en) autoloading together with core driver

Mellanox ethernet driver (mlx4_en) should be loaded together together with
core driver (mlx4_core).

This fix for default CentOS provision image taken from the libmlx4 package.

Change-Id: Ic1c26ff610fc657d05a854e81cf3681f3eeb0c45
Closes-Bug: #1501309
'}]
commit_message:
Mellanox ethernet driver (mlx4_en) autoloading together with core driver

Mellanox ethernet driver (mlx4_en) should be loaded together together with
core driver (mlx4_core).

This fix for default CentOS provision image taken from the libmlx4 package.

Change-Id: Ic1c26ff610fc657d05a854e81cf3681f3eeb0c45
Closes-Bug: #1501309

commit_message:
Mellanox ethernet driver (mlx4_en) autoloading together with core driver

Mellanox ethernet driver (mlx4_en) should be loaded together together with
core driver (mlx4_core).

This fix for default CentOS provision image taken from the libmlx4 package.

Change-Id: Ic1c26ff610fc657d05a854e81cf3681f3eeb0c45
Closes-Bug: #1501309

commit_message:
Point registry at tripleoupstream

The tripleoupstream registry contains images that are built
every time there is a change in delorean.

The gate also needs this.

Change-Id: If460853284588f637de820afa54069f773f2e6f7

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-14 18:59:55.000000000', 'message': 'Fixed broken assignment to dictionary using integer key

The case

$dict[$key]: value

for integer $key was not addressed in LHS expression logic.
As a result no changes were made to $dict and no error was raised.

Change-Id: I969dab5f0d32312cf52490945934557c32f22dde
Closes-Bug: #1515612
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed broken assignment to dictionary using integer key

The case

$dict[$key]: value

for integer $key was not addressed in LHS expression logic.
As a result no changes were made to $dict and no error was raised.

Change-Id: I969dab5f0d32312cf52490945934557c32f22dde

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-17 10:17:57.000000000', 'message': 'Leave only one provider to use by default

If both providers have *defaultfor* puppet uses not that which we are
waiting.

Change-Id: I33e88550af5d5cce2886254444ee5d450e578a1c
Closes-bug: #1510072
'}, {'created': '2015-11-17 13:18:14.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor configure_default_route function

Now if default route is needed to change we just modify network_scheme
and call generate_network_config with this network_scheme, if no - do
nothing.

Change-Id: I33e88550af5d5cce2886254444ee5d450e578a1c
Closes-bug: #1510072
'}, {'created': '2015-11-17 13:29:58.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor function configure_default_route

Before the function configure_default_route was a little part of function
generate_network_config which changed default gateway only, due to the provider
for interfaces was not picked correctly.
Now if default route is needed to change we just modify network_scheme
and call generate_network_config with this network_scheme, if no - do
nothing.

Change-Id: I33e88550af5d5cce2886254444ee5d450e578a1c
Closes-bug: #1510072
'}, {'created': '2015-11-17 20:56:01.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor function configure_default_route

Before the function configure_default_route was a little part of function
generate_network_config which changed default gateway only, due to the provider
for interfaces was not picked correctly.
Now if default route is needed to change we just modify network_scheme
