revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-23 17:43:00.000000000', 'message': 'Incorrect parsed variable name

database_user_create was not correctly referenced when parsing the
variable names. This could never actually lead to a situation that
reported a false change, but it could break an operation if you were
using the --step option with ansible and skipped the database create
task.

TrivialFix
Backport: Liberty

Partial-Bug: #1519040
Change-Id: Idf69fffcc3814f509448ccea11b7d175f074ccf1
(cherry picked from commit 6b283430173caf0d0ecabce55dfa62abfe68787a)
'}]
commit_message:
Incorrect parsed variable name

database_user_create was not correctly referenced when parsing the
variable names. This could never actually lead to a situation that
reported a false change, but it could break an operation if you were
using the --step option with ansible and skipped the database create
task.

TrivialFix
Backport: Liberty

Partial-Bug: #1519040
Change-Id: Idf69fffcc3814f509448ccea11b7d175f074ccf1
(cherry picked from commit 6b283430173caf0d0ecabce55dfa62abfe68787a)

I am investigating on it.'}, {'account_id': 17377, 'date': '2015-11-20 11:32:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24:

1b289eb Fix up issues after decomposition

Is this still needed after: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/218210/  ?'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2015-09-03 04:59:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

At the first look the other patch does not changes the JHOME in the start_opendaylight, and does not defaults to 8 at fedora-21 and above.'}, {'account_id': 333, 'date': '2015-09-04 00:35:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This should be on top of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/218210/

if necessary.
Probably if odl of a given version doesn't support java8, devstack should fail with error message."}, {'account_id': 17377, 'date': '2015-09-11 22:29:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Java 7 is still available from oracle. Please look at this change that installs Java 7 on fedora 21 (and probably 22).

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/218210/

It is already working for f21. It should in f22 but not tested. If you are interested in, you review and test it. 

I opened a bug in launch pad to keep trace of this problem.

https://bugs.launchpad.net/networking-odl/+bug/1467949

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-10-09 04:57:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think this one should be at least rebased on top of [1], if not abandoned altogether.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/218210/'}, {'account_id': 333, 'date': '2015-11-23 19:12:50.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Now https://review.openstack.org/#/c/218210/ is approved, this patch should be unnecessary.
Can you please test it? If anything wrong, please file it as a bug.(and hopefully bring a patch)'}]

commit_message:
Use java 1.8.0 on f21 and above

Jave 1.7.0 is not available in f21 and f22,
but java 1.8.0 is available.

Change-Id: I8bda9d777d0f16971f67cd094b14d3e0a10327f8

commit_message:
[install] Fix the Debian nova-compute node install

This patch fixes numerous issues in the nova-compute setup in Debian.
This is a 2nd attempt after the patch was reverted. Hopefuly, this
patch wont have issues with conditionals this time.

Change-Id: I03eedb6e6262e2a0484814a953a5787aca7b5624

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-11 20:58:55.000000000', 'message': "Adding support for error details on cluster creation

Cue's current implementation does not provide any additional information
to the user related to why a cluster went into ERROR state during
cluster creation.  This patch adds error_description field in the
clusters table and exposes this field through the API.  The
update_cluster_task now extracts failure flow details and forwards this
information on cluster record update.

Partial-Bug:  1508730
(updates also required to Cue client and dashboard)

Change-Id: I440fec30bc3d051189585479b8d2c1219a98cf40
"}, {'created': '2015-11-12 00:02:46.000000000', 'message': "Adding support for error details on cluster creation

Cue's current implementation does not provide any additional information

commit_message:
Adding support for error details on cluster creation

Cue's current implementation does not provide any additional information
to the user related to why a cluster went into ERROR state during
cluster creation.  This patch adds error_detail field in the
clusters table and exposes this field through the API.  The
update_cluster_task now extracts failure flow details and forwards this
information on cluster record update.

Partial-Bug:  1508730
(updates also required to Cue client and dashboard)
Closes-bug:  1516735
Change-Id: I440fec30bc3d051189585479b8d2c1219a98cf40

commit_message:
Renaming cluster update task

Cluster update task updates a cluster record in general, the previous
name implied it was only updating cluster status.

Change-Id: I912d829926e52ba11668f933481b364299f50fcc

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-20 16:06:52.000000000', 'message': 'Fix: Next cleaning hangs if the previous cleaning was aborted

When cleaning is abort Ironic leaves the node's clean_step field
populated with the step that was running at the moment. Because of that,
once the next cleaning starts again (after the node have been moved to
"manageable" and in the transition to "available") it will hang and
never finish, the reason for that is because once the node starts
heartbeating again Ironic won't know if the cleaning just started or
it's just continuing cleaning (it uses clean_step as a flag for it,
see the bug linked with this patch).

This patch fix this by cleaning up the node's clean_field once the
cleaning process is aborted.

Closes-Bug: #1518374
Change-Id: I423e89f9574a8952875ad9f03ce33298cb5660e7
'}]
commit_message:
Fix: Next cleaning hangs if the previous cleaning was aborted

When cleaning is abort Ironic leaves the node's clean_step field
populated with the step that was running at the moment. Because of that,
once the next cleaning starts again (after the node have been moved to
"manageable" and in the transition to "available") it will hang and
never finish, the reason for that is because once the node starts
heartbeating again Ironic won't know if the cleaning just started or
it's just continuing cleaning (it uses clean_step as a flag for it,
see the bug linked with this patch).

This patch fix this by cleaning up the node's clean_field once the
cleaning process is aborted.

Closes-Bug: #1518374

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-16 17:58:08.000000000', 'message': "Add clean up method for the DHCP factory

The DHCP provider base class has only update methods to notify the
provider which DHCP BOOT options to reserve when a node comes up. If anyone
wants to create his own DHCP provider implementation for Ironic, none of
the base class methods get triggered after a node is deleted, so the DHCP
reservations will be present even after the Ironic node is deleted.

This patch adds a 'clean_dhcp' method to the DHCPFactory class, which is used
to clean the DHCP BOOT options when an Ironic node is deleted. This is called
when an Ironic node is deleted.

Change-Id: Iec768268323204b39fa80731e22a2511c7ac7763
Closes-Bug: #1498923
"}, {'created': '2015-11-17 02:59:28.000000000', 'message': "Add clean up method for the DHCP factory

The DHCP provider base class has only update methods to notify the
provider which DHCP BOOT options to reserve when a node comes up. If anyone
wants to create his own DHCP provider implementation for Ironic, none of
the base class methods get triggered after a node is deleted, so the DHCP
reservations will be present even after the Ironic node is deleted.

This patch adds a 'clean_dhcp' method to the DHCPFactory class, which is used
to clean the DHCP BOOT options when an Ironic node is deleted. This is called
when an Ironic node is deleted.

Closes-Bug: #1498923

commit_message:
Add clean up method for the DHCP factory

The DHCP provider base class has only update methods to notify the
provider which DHCP BOOT options to reserve when a node comes up. If anyone
wants to create his own DHCP provider implementation for Ironic, none of
the base class methods get triggered after a node is deleted, so the DHCP
reservations will be present even after the Ironic node is deleted.

This patch adds a 'clean_dhcp' method to the DHCPFactory class, which is used
to clean the DHCP BOOT options. This is called when an Ironic node is torn down.

Closes-Bug: #1498923
Change-Id: Iec768268323204b39fa80731e22a2511c7ac7763

commit_message:
Resolve issue where router can't be removed from L3-agent in dvr mode

Fixes the problem where the L3 DVR Scheduler is unable
to remove a DVR router from a L3 agent running in
'dvr' mode.

Closes-bug: 1489091
Change-Id: Id128a81d2cf7108936715ee305012fbff23ffdbf
(cherry picked from commit 3de01b39b74d0a23f765b1f9b1a4ba1eb457068c)

There were typos in the Update Metadata modal description.
"In the left columns..." is clearly a typo, which should be
"In the left column..." Also, in the bug report there is another
issue: "Other" option should be "Custom".

commit_message:
Fixed Update Metadata modal description's typos

There were typos in the Update Metadata modal description.
"In the left columns..." is clearly a typo, which should be
"In the left column..." Also, in the bug report there is another
issue: "Other" option should be "Custom".

Change-Id: If4a82109aaa4f1ba18e1415af0ff197658abda2f
Closes-Bug: #1517296

It's possible to have complex formatting if you tell the YAML parser to preserve whitespace in the nested elements. See https://review.openstack.org/248861 for a new example in the docs.

It's possible to go back and edit this note file in a follow-up commit, if you want to improve the formatting. That said, keeping release notes simple is better than adding lots of nested elements and complex formatting, so don't abuse the ability to use lots of markup."}]

commit_message:
Add relnote for change in default setting

Commit 8ee49c6aedec4203fc7160b440923a86a983cd27 updated the
the default setting of 'CONF.vmware.integration_bridge'.

The value now is None.

Change-Id: Iaf107d2ba27fc2dc3c33efafb3199bc7161c0d6a

commit_message:
Fix example value for notification_topics

The value is not in the proper format, and it lead to an incorrect
value being parsed.

Change-Id: I36483561f80d5d5dec9a30bcb9f003df96250c3f
Closes-Bug: #1506831

commit_message:
Implement Advanced Firewalling support

Consume puppet-tripleo to create/manage IPtables from Heat templates.

This review put in place the logic to enable and setup firewall rules.

A known set of rules are applied. More to come.

Change-Id: Ib79c23fb27fe3fc03bf223e6922d896cb33dad22
Co-Authored-By: Yanis Guenane <yguenane@redhat.com>
Depends-On: I144c60db2a568a94dce5b51257f1d10980173325

[{'created': '2015-09-29 11:16:39.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Log warning for wrong migration flag config options

The config options live_migration_flag and block_migration_flag
of the [libvirt] section set the flags for the hypervisor for the
live-migration operation. It is possible to set the flags in a way
that every live-migration will be a block-migration and vice versa.
This doesn't make sense and is a misconfiguration.

Because some customers could already have configured their systems in
this faulty way, this patch set logs a warning if it discovers this,
instead of blocking the nova-compute service to come up.

Closes-Bug: #1499041
Change-Id: I37f1e90c8a86a1dcf0fc1e699a018e0784c66e48

commit_message:
libvirt: Log warning for wrong migration flag config options

The config options live_migration_flag and block_migration_flag
of the [libvirt] section set the flags for the hypervisor for the
live-migration operation. It is possible to set the flags in a way
that every live-migration will be a block-migration and vice versa.
This doesn't make sense and is a misconfiguration.

Because some customers could already have configured their systems in
this faulty way, this patch set logs a warning if it discovers this,
instead of blocking the nova-compute service to come up.

Closes-Bug: #1499041
Change-Id: I37f1e90c8a86a1dcf0fc1e699a018e0784c66e48

commit_message:
Remove self from image-create/image-update

Self is not meant to exist as it is a READ ONLY property, that is not
meant to exist as something the user can change.

Closes-bug: 1496024

commit_message:
Cause forbidden when deactivating image(non-admin)

If a user tries to deactivate an image that is hosted by the admin that
has public visiblity, it will currently return a 500 error. This changes
that behaviour to return a Forbidden.

Closes-Bug: 1485940
Change-Id: Id7f645fc599e57f6c0842bba2b7a2f3db52784ae

commit_message:
Cleanup time patching

Rather than create a mock and have to stop it, use
fixtures.MockPatchObject since it encapsulates the cleanup.

commit_message:
Ceph - how Fuel deploys

ref-arch/1300-ceph -- calls files in ceph subdirectory

moved ref-arch/1700-ceph that talked about Ceph MON into
the ceph subdirectory

terminology
- ceph -- full description of the "pieces" involved

ref-arch/network-concepts/6020-public-floating-ip
and ref-arch/neutron-intro/0260-neutron-config
threw build errors about header levels so I fixed them
although they are unrelated to this content

Change-Id: I97accd12b40fe3aa0d41a6b8831be0bc0bdf8b8d
Closes-Bug:1376654

commit_message:
Create openstack-infra/log_processor project

Create a project for the python files currently managed in
openstack-infra/puppet-log_processor. These scripts have grown to the
point were they should be made a proper python module. The scripts have
been copied to github.com/jesusaurus/log_processor preserving git
history using git-filter-branch.

Change-Id: I365e9272101f87761533169700193e6d19d2741a

commit_message:
Remove hardcoded LDAP group schema from emulated enabled mix-in

The emulated enabled mix-in uses hard-coded LDAP schema for the
group objectclass and membership attributes.  This patch makes the
mix-in optionally use the LDAP group configuration settings.

Change-Id: I5ed9d552ec140f83578398fd29e2130ebf827662
Closes-Bug: #1515302
(cherry picked from commit e465de5b44ffb1da65eab77ba7c81d1c0ced367f)

commit_message:
Moved node list to default application state

Rather than having a placeholder as the main view of
the application, we've moved the node list to the root
of the application. This brings the primary resource
for ironic to the forefront and immediately gives the
user something to do.

Change-Id: I6aaca2af1acd0ddeac58f1295438e64d45afaad2

commit_message:
Introduced Root State

The introduction of a root state permits us to move the overall
application layout to a location that is common to the entire
application. It reduces template duplication, and allows us
to specifically target view containers at any level of the
ui framework.

The ApplicationController has been renamed to describe its
new function, and a new 'main.html' template was added.
Note that there are quite a few whitespace changes, as
the indentation of many files changed when the encapsulating
div container moved to the global template.

Change-Id: I2d0b7147903f0af0560cd33903a1e6e4df309f55

'}, {'created': '2015-10-05 23:42:45.000000000', 'message': "Dynamically reconfiguring resources

This patch makes use of the new $$configuration provider,
the $$selectedConfiguration provider, and the $resourceCache,
to allow hot-swapping the current API without having to reload
the page. It also splits these resources out of the module.js file
into individual files (one file per thing best practice), adds tests,
and updates the coverage threshold accordingly.

The old resource factory method has been removed, as individual
service definitions have been pushed into the services themselves.
This gives them greater control over which actions they expose,
and what URL's those actions map to.

An edge case was identified which, due to the asynchronous
nature of configuration loading, could result in an API
request being issued while the selected configuration is either
invalid or not yet available. For this purpose a $$dummyResource
provider was added, so that the system does not throw
unexpected errors.

Change-Id: I7f6542631266d481e5b847a7e4b9d08057801ba8
"}, {'created': '2015-11-19 18:18:05.000000000', 'message': "Dynamically reconfiguring resources

This gives them greater control over which actions they expose,

commit_message:
Dynamically reconfiguring resources

This patch makes use of the new $$configuration provider,
the $$selectedConfiguration provider, and the $resourceCache,
to allow hot-swapping the current API without having to reload
the page. It also splits these resources out of the module.js file
into individual files (one file per thing best practice), adds tests,
and updates the coverage threshold accordingly.

The old resource factory method has been removed, as individual
service definitions have been pushed into the services themselves.
This gives them greater control over which actions they expose,
and what URL's those actions map to.

An edge case was identified which, due to the asynchronous
nature of configuration loading, could result in an API
request being issued while the selected configuration is either
invalid or not yet available. For this purpose a $$dummyResource
provider was added, so that the system does not throw
unexpected errors.

Change-Id: I7f6542631266d481e5b847a7e4b9d08057801ba8

commit_message:
Remove unneeded volume serialization

It looks like this serialization introduced
because of some rebase, anyway it's clear that
it's unneeded.

Closes-bug: 1494650
Change-Id: If0140ca9f22fb3073fafccada512c877322efc2d
(cherry picked from commit faef6379cb1f7ba0ec70dfcbcb61c8d60b17518a)

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-20 14:21:21.000000000', 'message': 'Report stack_status_reason on heat failure

When stack create fails, report the status reason, instead
of just the status. This gives the user useful information about
the cause of the failure (out of floating IPs, etc.) instead of
just "CREATE_FAILED".

Change-Id: Ibbaf14e8959cecfade98d13f8101e333eb76ee6e
Closes-Bug: 1516016
(cherry picked from commit dec8f7ab922c2ab454afe9c58842650ba701a2cc)
'}]
commit_message:
Report stack_status_reason on heat failure

When stack create fails, report the status reason, instead
of just the status. This gives the user useful information about
the cause of the failure (out of floating IPs, etc.) instead of
just "CREATE_FAILED".

Change-Id: Ibbaf14e8959cecfade98d13f8101e333eb76ee6e
Closes-Bug: 1516016
(cherry picked from commit dec8f7ab922c2ab454afe9c58842650ba701a2cc)

commit_message:
Set logging level same as other fuel services

Astute was the only fuel service using short ERR and CRIT log levels,
it led to unconvinient log viewing using the WebUI.

Change-Id: I3dd8e7d80030f6a16d910ee28950102b31765af5
Closes-bug: #1286110

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

One general comment: this patchset is hard to review because you are mixing up several things. You have the documentation change, the code change, as well as a lot of unrelated formatting changes all mixed into one.

It really would make things much clearer if you kept these separate. I would suggest submitting the code change first, and making the doc changes in separate patches, dependent on the code patch. If you have any questions about how to do this, I would be happy to help.'}, {'account_id': 18971, 'date': '2015-11-20 15:59:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I agree with the fact that this changeset is kind of too big. The thing is that this changeset triggered some discussion internally so we can have a separate refactoring blueprint (see https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/refactor-watcher-objects-and-packages).
At the same time, there is another changeset (see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/246534/) which is partly overlaping with what I am doing here (on bits that are just noises).

So to clarify the situation to you, I am waiting for the latter changeset to get merged and will then narrow down the number of files my changeset currently impacts.

For the .rst documentation, I can split it in 2 reviews but since both are linked together, I'm not sure whether it's worth splitting the changeset in 2, unless it is still hard to read at this point in time.

I hope this answers your question :)"}, {'account_id': 19214, 'date': '2015-11-20 16:53:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-11-23 10:06:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified-1

commit_message:
Made Decision Engine extensible via stevedore

The objective for this is to give the ability to extend the default
set of placement algorithms (i.e. strategies) currently available
in Watcher using Stevedore.

Now, you can add your new strategy as an entry point under the
'[watcher_strategies]' section.

Change-Id: I4aecf629015e41b0389d07e47220333e50bbbe1a

status in os-server-external-events is optional

os-server-external-events's status request param is optional
and default to 'completed'

commit_message:
Add response params for GET image members

This commit adds following params into response parameter for
GET v2/images{image_id}/members:
  * members
  * created_at
  * image_id
  * member_id
  * status
  * updated_at
  * schema(member)

Change-Id: Iad31516e70f4ae2ab4f2a82eea79042b6ab453a3
Closes-Bug: #1518880

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

(1 comment)

So I understand what you want to do here and I don't think it's worth doing. I will not -1 this, but would love to see the actual use case for having the cinder attachment ID here other than to be pedantic."}, {'account_id': 13248, 'date': '2015-10-02 15:18:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Hi Nikola, I think volume_attachment.id will help cloud admin to distinguish the attachments in the cloud. Using volume.id as volume_attachment.id in nova api will introduce confusion in two ways.

1. Same attachment has different ids: nova api(GET http://(IP):8774/v2.1/(tenant-id)/servers/(instance-id)/os-volume_attachments) and cinder api(GET http://(IP):8776/v2/(tenant-id)/volumes/(volume-id)) will return different attachment ids for same attachment;

2. Different attachments have same id: in multi-attach case, a volume can be attached to more than one instances, then nova api will return the same id for different attachments.'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2015-10-07 09:10:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2015-10-07 14:31:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

What Nikola said is something that I was concerned too in my previous reviews.
I agree that the user should ask cinder to get the information about volume attachments ids (if he really needs), at this point I am wonder if it would be better for nova not returning that value at all so this will "discourage" people to use Nova API as a proxy for cinder API.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2015-10-08 18:16:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

Unless there is a need for this for the multi-attach case in cinder (which hasn't been fleshed out yet from what I know), I don't see the need for this proxy solution to the volume API.

As Andrea points out, about the only thing I could maybe agree with is not returning the id to avoid confusion."}, {'account_id': 13248, 'date': '2015-10-12 05:43:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Thanks all four your comments, now I understand proxy to other components is discouraged in OS API.
What about the 'volume.id' nova API returns, I noticed some of you also think that's confusing, is it necessary to exclude the 'id' attribute from nova API response?"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2015-10-13 17:11:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

At this point I'd consider this change more or less stuck.  I don't think we're going to allow the proxy change, but the question of whether or not to return the id attribute in the response is something that you could bring up in the -dev mailing list for Nova and/or post to the weekly nova meeting under the 'stuck reviews' section so we can discuss there as a team."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2015-11-20 11:14:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

agree this one should be abandoned, we're not going to make this change."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-11-23 16:32:58.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This one seems suck, please use the usual channels to resolve that.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2015-11-23 16:53:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

*stuck

:)'}]

(3 comments)

Most part seems nice for me.

I think it is more better to describe the way of min/max microversion clearly.
There are two ways for these versions, as headers, or in a body.

Maybe as the guideline, I guess we will recommend the server needs to return min/max versions always *as headers*, and return these versions *in a body* when version mismatching error happens, right?

If so, the above description will help understanding.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2015-06-15 16:54:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

One thing I would like to see in this is an explanation of why accept and content-type headers with versioned media-types are not being used. That is, an explanation for why content negotiation, to which this is similar, was not used. That will likely help preempt any questions that come up in that vein and also help illuminate some of the decision making process in this design.

(Note: I'm not suggesting that we do use content negotiation simply that the explanation of why we aren't will be illumunating.)"}, {'account_id': 10670, 'date': '2015-10-12 16:24:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(17 comments)

Alex, in general i really like the content but there are several nits i have with the grammar and layout.'}, {'account_id': 1112, 'date': '2015-10-12 17:17:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

We need to remove 'X-' header prefix everywhere in this guideline to be consistent with the headers guideline [1]. We need to ask ourselves this, how can we expect the APIs to be consistent if the guidelines can't be consistent?

The way to handle the backwards compat issue is to have Nova and Ironic send both 'X-OpenStack' and 'OpenStack' headers. It's not appropriate to force 'X-OpenStack' on every other project just because 2 projects used it.

[1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/headers.html"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2015-10-22 22:02:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Add introduction for API microversion guideline

This specification is reference to Nova and Ironic API
microversion implementation:
https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/blob/master/specs/kilo/implemented/api-microversions.rst
https://github.com/openstack/ironic-specs/blob/master/specs/kilo/api-microversions.rst

Current API microversion is different from common versioning SemVer,
so it is nice to go forward with small steps for bulding a consensus.

Change-Id: Ie10b8cf78fab43f437ae3ec7adb7f243de0505af

I feel like the code should prioritize being fixed over being human readable. The title and description should change over time as necessary, and likely be translatable, but the code should not change due to il8n or terminology shifting (any error code that had tenant in it, for example, would create an issue as that term has been replaced by project).

Where possible the error code should be human-friendly, not require a decoder ring, and even be more specific than an HTTP Status Code when possible, but not at the cost of introducing the potential for casual mutation.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2015-04-06 10:39:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

LGTM, but I think in most situations there's going to be a single error, which forces all clients to do `response.errors[0].whatever` all the time. I suggest having the most significant error under a required "error" key, and making the "errors" key optional.'}, {'account_id': 12321, 'date': '2015-09-08 17:43:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@Miguel: I think the extra complexity there (requiring a single error key and also including an array) isn't necessary. Sure, always indexing to the first element is more effort, but I think that would increase the potential to confuse implementors and lead to many ever-so-slightly differing versions in practice.

Having all errors in a single array is a simpler path forward, and that makes it more attractive IMO."}, {'account_id': 15171, 'date': '2015-09-09 14:01:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I don't believe my comments are deal breakers, especially if it is too early to add the notes I mentioned from the JSON API Errors page. That said, I do think that if the JSON API Errors page is the basis for this, we should be a bit more explicit what we're re-using."}, {'account_id': 6800, 'date': '2015-09-09 14:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Please add a field for a *machine-readable* error code. The `code` is not specific enough; we need a field that identifies the error in a way that a machine can make decisions based on the error. This is crucial for using APIs in automation software.'}, {'account_id': 8434, 'date': '2015-09-10 20:12:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Looks good.  I agree that the error codes for log messages are not needed in the response body and the removal of them makes the response body much cleaner. It makes lots of sense, but it wasn't immediately obvious until clearly stated here. 

The request-id should be enough to match occurrences to log messages.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2015-09-11 11:37:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I'm concerned that this proposal doesn't include a machine-parsable indication of what error is. An example of what I'm thinking of is here:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/errors-overview.html

An API call can fail in ways that require a significantly different response from the caller. HTTP status codes are far too coarse for this."}, {'account_id': 1112, 'date': '2015-09-12 00:22:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

It truly pained me to remove the machine readable code from this guideline because the OpenStack wide error codes spec [1] didn't get traction.

But thinking about it further, I don't want to totally disallow the possibility of including some kind of machine readable code in errors. The potential for users to build more robust applications because they can work with an error code is too great. 

As such I'm putting the code back in but making it non-required and not referring to [1] in any way. However, note that the definition of the format of the code is way outside the scope of this guideline and will not be addressed here.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/172552/"}, {'account_id': 1112, 'date': '2015-09-12 00:22:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-09-12 00:26:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified+1

- gate-api-wg-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/93/167793/7/check/gate-api-wg-python27/2051529/ : SUCCESS in 2m 11s'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2015-09-14 12:44:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

The application-specific error code would certainly be good if applied, but given this is a guideline document I think you really do need to go there.

I read the spec you linked for machine readable error code. In my view, these are quite different things. An api needs to define different reasons why a specific api call has failed, as these require different actions by the user. Consider EACCESS and EEXIST as returned by open(2): 1 you give up, the other you can try something else. However, these are generic errors. Reporting EEXIST to a sysadmin with no context is utterly useless. However, it's useful to the API user because they know which open call returned it.

The errors discussed in the other spec are intended to identify a specific failure in a specific bit of code to a sysadmin so they can google what to do about it. This kind of message is inherently loaded with context, so out of disk space on an NFS share, and out of space in an LVM volume group are quite different things. However, to the API user they are, and must remain forever, the same thing. They are part of the API itself.

I don't think it's worth shuffling this code without addressing this. I have only consumed the openstack api once, and I was completely taken aback by this omission. I can't think of another API I have used which doesn't define its errors, and it makes it extremely hard to use robustly."}, {'account_id': 1112, 'date': '2015-09-14 15:23:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

@Matthew Your first sentence says exactly why the definition of the code is outside the scope of this guideline, "application-specific".

The role of the API WG is to provide guidelines that promote consistency across all OpenStack APIs. The API WG does not get into implementation details and especially nothing application-specific.'}, {'account_id': 15171, 'date': '2015-09-14 16:15:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

@Everett Thanks for the clarifications. This makes for a great guideline. Also, I think the comments from others regarding things like programmatic fields and known error messages need to be fleshed out in the real world and linked to these guidelines once there is a clearer best practice to promote. I'd say if others have strong opinions, a better tactic could be to try and get something like an authoritative error message list applied upstream and use that as an example here."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2015-09-14 16:53:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

'Application specific' is the term used in the doc. I just used it.

If you don't define this field, it will be used inconsistently and/or not at all. Consequently it will be completely useless from the start. In order to gain some measure of usability whilst maintaining compatibility, we will be forced to retain this field, and add another field which is well defined.

I agree that you don't want to be in the business of defining the errors themselves in this doc, but you do need to define the process for creating and managing a consistent and meaningful taxonomy of errors, and guidelines for how it should be applied. This doesn't have to be heavy handed. For a starter, how about:

All apis SHOULD set this field.
If an api sets this field, its value MUST be from the list located at X.

X is a cross-project list. Adding entries to it can have its own guidelines, which promotes consistent re-use of generic errors. This would also add an automatic additional review process to the creation of new errors, which is likely to be a good thing. After an initial rush, we should expect them to be created rarely."}, {'account_id': 7437, 'date': '2015-09-17 19:24:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Here's some prior art from the general API space:
https://github.com/blongden/vnd.error , for comparison.

Given that things are similar and many of the differences are down to taste, I'd say the error proposal is on the right track.  It would be perhaps nice to just extend vnd.error, but it's not like vnd.error is an RFC or anything.

One thought, however:

The OpenStack API has a fragmentary treatment of link relations.  I was looking through the Nova API and sometimes the links are objects with a `href` and a `rel` key, thus allowing code to naively walk the response.  c.f. the response to POST /v2.1/​{tenant_id}​/servers versus the request.  This is just the after-effect of the piecemeal nature of the API development.

I do like the concept of how the vnd.error breaks the URLs out into three semantic categories, with options for more.  This should allow providers to provide progressively richer information.  Also, given that none of the existing errror formats don't have URLs available at all, this seems like a good opportunity to drive things forwards."}, {'account_id': 8434, 'date': '2015-09-22 22:39:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

A standard for the error code is important, but it's not part of *this* spec.  And I hope to get more traction for error codes in Tokyo.  But that said, wherever the error code standards are defined, this  guideline can refer to them "Error Codes will follow the OpenStack standard. If there is no standard, the field will remain empty."  Or something similar.

Acknowledge they are wanted and desired and what to do when they don't exist.  Then the Error Code standard can refer to *this* guideline to strengthen its relevancy.

I think a placeholder is adequate to get this guideline out there.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2015-11-05 17:09:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1112, 'date': '2015-11-06 05:13:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

I'm good with this. One suggestion inline to use JSON+HAL _links representation, but that's just a recommendation nothing more.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 1112, 'date': '2015-11-23 16:22:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

@Rocky JSON doesn't support multi-line strings and mixing layout (e.g. adding "\n") with content is undesirable and won't actually solve the problem you're describing. And the JSON Schema must stay independent of the layout so it can be used for validation. Once the guideline is published you can view that JSON file in your web browser which will do line wrapping for you.

@Jay I deliberately chose LDO based on Michael's analysis of linking [1] where LDO is clearly the predominant style. I'm going to leave it as is for this patch but I'm open to someone creating a guideline for links in the near future and updating this guideline based on that.

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/API_Working_Group/Current_Design/Links'}, {'account_id': 10670, 'date': '2015-11-23 16:27:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-11-23 16:40:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: -Verified

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-25 20:59:13.000000000', 'message': 'A guideline for errors

Errors are a crucial part of the developer experience when using an API. As
developers learn the API they inevitably run into errors. The quality and
consistency of the error messages returned to them will play a large part
in how quickly they can learn the API, how they can be more effective with
the API, and how much they enjoy using the API.

We need consistency across all services for the error format returned in
the response body.

Change-Id: Iae6dc4d84c11c95a97d2451668ebffa80c9821ec

commit_message:
A guideline for errors

Errors are a crucial part of the developer experience when using an API. As
developers learn the API they inevitably run into errors. The quality and
consistency of the error messages returned to them will play a large part
in how quickly they can learn the API, how they can be more effective with
the API, and how much they enjoy using the API.

We need consistency across all services for the error format returned in
the response body.

Change-Id: Iae6dc4d84c11c95a97d2451668ebffa80c9821ec

commit_message:
config options: enhance help text of section "serial_console"

The help text of the config options got enhanced to improve the quality
of their documentation. I used a syntax which is in the ReST format.

bp centralize-config-options

Change-Id: I01a2070691035126b8d92be6e810ac3339347b75

commit_message:
Reverse sort tables before archiving

sqlalchemy metadata provides a way to sort tables based on foreign
key dependency relationships and then we can reverse sort those to
process leaf nodes first when archiving deleted records. Use this
to at least attempt to archive things in a sane order.

Adds a functional test to cover this since the unit tests for archive
are setup in such a way that they don't stress many of the tables
related to a created instance record and thus miss some fundamental
referential constraint failures during archive.

This does not completely fix archive_deleted_rows because of the issue
with instance_actions not being soft deleted when instances are deleted,
which we still need to sort out, but this at least gives us a functional
test that stresses a real usage of the DB API. And since the tables are
now sorted we can reliably assert the archive results.

Partial-Bug: #1183523

Change-Id: I948b149239f01cca2d4156611bb883580a216a83

[{'created': '2015-11-16 23:17:48.000000000', 'message': "Clean up legacy multi-version test constructs

This removes MyObj2 and MyObjDiffVers from the tests, and fixes up the
tests that still use them to use the more modern manifest-based approach,
which is much cleaner and doesn't require strangely subclassed objects
to mimic the multi-version environment during an upgrade.

It also removes a few tests that still do some basic validation on the
object registry, which is now fully contained (and tested) inside of
oslo.versionedobjects.

Change-Id: Ia523f3264b0ea54573e54c258efd7a07158ded36
"}]
commit_message:
Clean up legacy multi-version test constructs

This removes MyObj2 and MyObjDiffVers from the tests, and fixes up the
tests that still use them to use the more modern manifest-based approach,
which is much cleaner and doesn't require strangely subclassed objects
to mimic the multi-version environment during an upgrade.

It also removes a few tests that still do some basic validation on the
object registry, which is now fully contained (and tested) inside of
oslo.versionedobjects.

Change-Id: Ia523f3264b0ea54573e54c258efd7a07158ded36

commit_message:
Mark set-admin-password as complete for libvirt in support matrix

The set-admin-password virt driver API was implemented for libvirt
qemu/kvm x86 in liberty per 520a6b92853cf0f6ef183df78c41c70ee0b8cfab but
the hypervisor support matrix wasn't updated.

This updates the support matrix and also adds notes that libvirt 1.2.16
is required along with hw_qemu_guest_agent configuration in the backing
image.

Closes-Bug: #1511114

Change-Id: Iee1d628116cad8c0c60c8335a2910b3c4e1b5e2d

Before it comes up. 

The {var} syntax in jsonhome href-template variables provides a key into the dictionary of parameters provided in href-vars. I can therefore change the var name so long as there is a corresponding key in the href-vars. Because the value of href-vars has not changed then the key lookup still returns the same type parameter.

commit_message:
Use idp_id and protocol_id in jsonhome

These are inconsistent with the rest of the federation routes. Note that
this doesn't change a public interface, it changes the path variables
names that exist within a jsonhome document which should only be
referenced within the same href_vars element and some internal variable
names.

Change-Id: I36d41e95d745bd98d36c3442bd4aa4faa91cab72
Closes-Bug: #1420125

commit_message:
Remove double API requests

When a keystone session object is used API call are done twice.

This change fixes that.

Change-Id: I79815520b996bce954fe531193f1a0229ef30060

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-10-02 22:16:43.000000000', 'message': 'Data Security Enforcements In Nova

Enterprises need to be compliant with data security laws and regulations that
require sensitive data to be encrypted at rest (storage) as well in motion
(over the wire). Nova has features such as transparent data encryption that
can be utilized as part of a data security compliance plan. We propose
implementing checks inside Nova that will ensure that such features are
enabled. These checks will be triggered based on the presence of specific
metadata defined on an image. Such declaration based enforcements can provide
additional confidence to the operators tasked with setting up a secure cloud
and thereby provide impetus to the enterprise adoption of OpenStack.

Change-Id: I0618bf381d1868af7facf991d22e2e8113794193
'}, {'created': '2015-10-03 00:13:58.000000000', 'message': 'Data Security Enforcements In Nova

commit_message:
Data Security Enforcements In Nova

Enterprises need to be compliant with data security laws and regulations that
require sensitive data to be encrypted at rest (storage) as well in motion
(over the wire). Nova has features such as transparent data encryption that
can be utilized as part of a data security compliance plan. We propose
implementing checks inside Nova that will ensure that such features are
enabled. These checks will be triggered based on the presence of specific
metadata defined on an image. Such declaration based enforcements can provide
additional confidence to the operators tasked with setting up a secure cloud
and thereby provide impetus to the enterprise adoption of OpenStack.

Change-Id: I0618bf381d1868af7facf991d22e2e8113794193

I think the "Step<N>" bits are conventions for the heat breakpoints to know what to stop on. So while the ringbuilder bit uses a different manifest, it's still a step in controller deployment in a greater sense. I don't feel strongly about the -1 but i think we should let shardy look at this before we merge. I'll add him as a reviewer.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2015-05-18 14:42:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Yeah, please don't do this, it will break https://review.openstack.org/#/c/161927/9

The Deployment_StepN naming convention must be consistent for us to use wildcards in the hook definition, e.g see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/182381/

The alternative is to specify the hooks longhand, e.g list every single Deployment resource explicitly in the environment, but the wildcard-with-naming-convention approach seems like less maintenance effort to me."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-18 15:19:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-06-04 15:58:16.000000000', 'message': 'Improve support for REMOTE_OPERATIONS in manual runs

This submission applies a number of small changes which made me
to complete successully the build of a seed VM using the
REMOTE_OPERATIONS parameter set to "1" (that is, devtest running
on a distinct host with remote access to libvirtd).

A few notes about the changes:
 * uniforms checks for REMOTE_OPERATIONS using -n rather than != 1
 * removes occurrences of 'sudo virsh' which would not honour the
   user (devtest) defined LIBVIRT_DEFAULT_URI parameter
 * skips chattr +C when images are not available locally

Change-Id: Ib2ce2926fe02a0f5f370a81495cfc192db8b3427
'}]
commit_message:
Improve support for REMOTE_OPERATIONS in manual runs

This submission applies a number of small changes which made me
to complete successully the build of a seed VM using the
REMOTE_OPERATIONS parameter set to "1" (that is, devtest running
on a distinct host with remote access to libvirtd).

A few notes about the changes:
 * uniforms checks for REMOTE_OPERATIONS using -n rather than != 1
 * removes occurrences of 'sudo virsh' which would not honour the
   user (devtest) defined LIBVIRT_DEFAULT_URI parameter
 * skips chattr +C when images are not available locally

Change-Id: Ib2ce2926fe02a0f5f370a81495cfc192db8b3427

Change-Id: I1d324af84a070753185a104924afec8e0ffb1155

commit_message:
Do not pass public to keystone.initialize

In os-cloud-config public is preferred to host if passed so this
change avoids us passing public.

Change-Id: I1d324af84a070753185a104924afec8e0ffb1155

commit_message:
Remove file locks from drivers to support HA A/A

This spec outlines work needed for volume nodes to remove local file
locks from Storage Drivers so syncrhonization is possible among Volume
nodes.

This is one of the aspects that are needed to support Active/Active in
cinder.

Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-active-active-support
Change-Id: I3b94d3bce4c61a344cac073f5f0eafc5a70d233f

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2014-05-02 18:02:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Not updating nova's notion of the hostname if neutron decides it has to be different (because of DNS rules or a conflict) is not okay, IMHO. We've made a lot of progress towards making sure that nova and neutron do not give conflicting data to the user and this seems specifically intending to ignore that goal.

Personally, I think that if nova tells the user that the hostname is different than it is, and it's different because that hostname is already in use (the most common reason it will be different), then that's a huge problem. Sure, the user should be checking host keys, but seriously, if nova tells me what the hostname is and I ssh to it, I expect that I'm hitting the box I was given.

All it takes is updating nova's notion of the hostname for this once we know what neutron agreed to, which I think is completely reasonable."}, {'account_id': 7769, 'date': '2014-05-02 19:08:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Nice work Carl.

I have to agree with Dan on his feedback. We've implemented something somewhat similar to this patch privately and we were forced to make arbitrary conversions to acceptable neutron names with no feedback to nova. This is not really acceptable here.

With that said, it is not at all unreasonable to me that we simply include forced updates to nova when the hostname is updated if neutron determines it knows better. There are other examples of this pattern so this is not new territory.

If that was included I would happily approve."}, {'account_id': 7448, 'date': '2014-05-05 18:34:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Dan, I can see that you feel very passionate about this.  I'm trying to make sense of your comment and figure out what it is you think I'm specifically intending to ignore.  I now see your comment -- "so I wonder if we can just expose what we know neutron accepted to the user like this and still avoid a breaking API change?" -- differently than I did the first time given your recent clarification.  I did not intend to ignore it.  It was just not clear to me what you were trying to say the first time.

Neutron sends updates to Nova when ports are active.  I could use those updates to send an update to the hostname to Nova.  Would you find that acceptible?

My argument before was specifically contradicting the claim that this blueprint introduces a security problem.  I stand by that.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-05 18:35:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 7448, 'date': '2014-05-05 18:42:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-05 18:42:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/50/90150/7/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/5145c42/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 58s'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-05-07 17:22:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

See in-line of comments / requests for clarification.

I think everyone it makes sense that both Nova and Neutron have the same view on the hostname assigned to a particular port/instance.

I'm wondering if it wouldn't be simpler to just add the required validation into Nova (conditional on some config flag so deployers can choose when to introduce this) so that Nova can be configured to always pass an acceptable name into Neutron.   Then if that flag is set in Nova it:
 - validates the name against the criteria that Neutron would/will use (oslo ?)
 - passes the name to Neutron via the hostname attribute
 - treats any failure from Neutron as an error condition"}, {'account_id': 7448, 'date': '2014-05-08 18:41:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

(6 comments)

Phil, great feedback, thank you!  I will take a look and see what needs to change in this blueprint and resubmit.

Here are some reasons why I did not propose doing validation in Nova.
1.  Neutron still needs the validation in its API.
2.  I don't want to break existing workflows by suddenly producing errors for names that used to be acceptable.
3.  Reviewers don't like adding new config flags and I don't either.  (See previous comments)"}, {'account_id': 7448, 'date': '2014-05-08 18:55:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-08 18:55:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-08 19:01:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/50/90150/8/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/54e380d : SUCCESS in 53s
- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/50/90150/8/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/f9a0a8a/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 05s'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-05-09 12:54:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Still a -1 on this as I'd at least like to see the alternative of doing name validation in Nova celled out and discussed - as most of the complexity in the BP seems to come from deferring that to Neutron and then having to feed the result back into Nova.

I think it would be a much better user experience if the name failed validation during server create that if it gets mutated by the system without prior warning.

Yes that would mean a change in Nova that then needs to be explictly enabled, and hence configured somehow (could be an API extension so that users can detect it), and yes we have too many config values of those already - but that shouldn't mean that automatically any new config value is blocked if it can avoid a more complex change and facilitate a smooth transition."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-09 18:11:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Starting check jobs.

commit_message:
Catch exception raised by keystoneauth1

We must support session object that comes from keystoneauth1 and
keystoneclient.

This change adds code path for keystoneauth1 when it misses.

Change-Id: I1164a0a0745605b6bc4fd1fc8fb2813c7e40fb9b

commit_message:
Allow building prepared images for Ironic

Sahara-image-elements should be able to build prepared
images for Ironic. Per documentation [1], we should include
several elements during image building.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/deploy/install-guide.html#image-requirements
Change-Id: Id1d4335230b24e4fc4c46b60c70ddd9bae6ea217

Currently Designate is undergoing a code freeze to allow us re-factor the code base,
as announced here: - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-October/077442.html

All code that is not in the "the-big-rename" topic will be getting this procedural -2.

More information can be found here: - http://graham.hayes.ie/posts/the-big-rename/

On Friday 2015-11-13 this -2 will be removed, and code review as normal will continue.

This re-factor will break the majority of patches that are outstanding, and you may need to manually
rebase your patch when we remove the -2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-11-11 15:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Currently Designate is undergoing a code freeze to allow us re-factor the code base,
as announced here: - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-October/077442.html

All code that is not in the "the-big-rename" topic will be getting this procedural -2.

More information can be found here: - http://graham.hayes.ie/posts/the-big-rename/

On Friday 2015-11-13 this -2 will be removed, and code review as normal will continue.

This re-factor will break the majority of patches that are outstanding, and you may need to manually
rebase your patch when we remove the -2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-11-12 14:04:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-21 01:20:04.000000000', 'message': 'Use standard credential_id parameter in jsonhome

The EC2 jsonhome credential_id is referenced as a parameter unique to
EC2. This is actually just the standard credential_id parameter that
keystone core uses.

Change-Id: I588d2af27116562039dae9d1c51cc877e74d5e9c
'}]
commit_message:
Use standard credential_id parameter in jsonhome

The EC2 jsonhome credential_id is referenced as a parameter unique to
EC2. This is actually just the standard credential_id parameter that
keystone core uses.

Change-Id: I588d2af27116562039dae9d1c51cc877e74d5e9c

commit_message:
Disable DevStack/Tempest runs

Some config options were renamed in tempest, which our Kilo
devstack/tempest code relies on. Update these to the new
names, but that's still not enough. Disable these tests
on Kilo until we can figure this out.

Change-Id: I41f30ab24bffa60444f2cd42dc15c583edc91953

commit_message:
libvirt: support pvpanic device

Add support for a pvpanic device for instances.

blueprint libvirt-enable-pvpanic

Change-Id: I80c4ed30b5b5895c6fa7ee5126fd915679a8246f

commit_message:
WIP: Add update environment directory and sample file

This change adds an 'update' directory within 'environments' were we
can store additional environment files to be optionally used for an
update.

Also adds an initial 'update-from-vip.yaml' and a README.md file
documenting when is appropriate to use it.

Change-Id: Ic28286f5d699d89de943585f5bc910eb91b7d573

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-06 02:07:04.000000000', 'message': 'Python3-readiness for antlr3 pieces

Purpose: Make antlr code Python3-ready while keeping Python2 support

Changes:
- Generated Python3 CongressParser.py and CongressLexer.py placed in
subpackage congress/datalog/Python3/ (using antlr 3.5.2)
- Moved original CongressParser.py and CongressLexer.py into new
subpackage congress/datalog/Python2/
- Changed import section in congress/datalog/compiler.py to import
the appropriate subpackage based on python version used
- Removed original symlink antlr3 to the antlr3-python2 runtime
- Changed setup.py to create the appropriate antlr3 symlink based on
python version
- Changed the error reporting interface of antlr3-python3 runtime to
be compatible with what existing Congress code expects
(thirdparty/antlr3-antlr-3.5/runtime/Python3/antlr3/recognizers.py)

Result: tox -e py34 no longer reports any errors traced to antlr code.

Notes:
- Supporting both Python versions was not straightforward because
neither the antlr runtime nor the antlr generated code is
cross-version compatible.
- Making symlinks via setup.py is not ideal, but the best solution
I came up with among several I considered. If you have better ideas
please suggest.
- Making our own custom changes to antlr3-python3 runtime is not
ideal, but it was necessary because for some reason the
antlr3-python3 runtime broke error reporting interface compatibility
with antlr3-python2 runtime, leading to test failures in
test_compile.py and test_congress.py.
In theory, supporting our custom changes in antlr3 runtime bad, but
because antlr3 is not supported anyway, the situation is really no
worse than before. In addition, the changes are fairly minor.
- antlr4 was not adopted because it does not have support for
abstract syntax trees.

Change-Id: I376aee803c4dc9953c1b5ba9311cf9c4a42f3319
'}, {'created': '2015-11-06 02:14:06.000000000', 'message': 'Python3-readiness for antlr3 pieces

- Changed setup.py to create the appropriate antlr3 symlink based on
python version
- Changed the error reporting interface of antlr3-python3 runtime to
be compatible with what existing Congress code expects
(thirdparty/antlr3-antlr-3.5/runtime/Python3/antlr3/recognizers.py)

Result: tox -e py34 no longer reports any errors traced to antlr code.

Notes:
- Supporting both Python versions was not straightforward because
neither the antlr runtime nor the antlr generated code is
cross-version compatible.
- Making symlinks via setup.py is not ideal, but the best solution
I came up with among several I considered. If you have better ideas
please suggest.
- Making our own custom changes to antlr3-python3 runtime is not
ideal, but it was necessary because for some reason the
antlr3-python3 runtime broke error reporting interface compatibility
with antlr3-python2 runtime, leading to test failures in
test_compile.py and test_congress.py.
In theory, supporting our custom changes in antlr3 runtime bad, but
because antlr3 is not supported anyway, the situation is really no
worse than before. In addition, the changes are fairly minor.
- antlr4 was not adopted because it does not have support for
abstract syntax trees.

Partially implements blueprint: support-python3

Change-Id: I376aee803c4dc9953c1b5ba9311cf9c4a42f3319

In theory, supporting our custom changes in antlr3 runtime bad, but
because antlr3 is not supported anyway, the situation is really no
worse than before. In addition, the changes are fairly minor.
- antlr4 was not adopted because it does not have support for
abstract syntax trees.

Partially implements blueprint: support-python3

Change-Id: I376aee803c4dc9953c1b5ba9311cf9c4a42f3319
'}]
commit_message:
Python3-readiness for antlr3 pieces

Purpose: Make antlr code Python3-ready while keeping Python2 support

Changes:
- Generated Python3 CongressParser.py and CongressLexer.py placed in
subpackage congress/datalog/Python3/ (using antlr 3.5.2)
- Moved original CongressParser.py and CongressLexer.py into new
subpackage congress/datalog/Python2/
- Changed import section in congress/datalog/compiler.py to import
the appropriate subpackage based on python version used
- Removed original symlink antlr3 to the antlr3-python2 runtime
- Changed setup.py to create the appropriate antlr3 symlink based on
python version
- Changed the error reporting interface of antlr3-python3 runtime to
be compatible with what existing Congress code expects
(thirdparty/antlr3-antlr-3.5/runtime/Python3/antlr3/recognizers.py)

Result: tox -e py34 no longer reports any errors traced to antlr code.

Notes:
- Supporting both Python versions was not straightforward because
neither the antlr runtime nor the antlr generated code is
cross-version compatible.
- Making symlinks via setup.py is not ideal, but the best solution
I came up with among several I considered. If you have better ideas
please suggest.
- Making our own custom changes to antlr3-python3 runtime is not
ideal, but it was necessary because for some reason the
antlr3-python3 runtime broke error reporting interface compatibility
with antlr3-python2 runtime, leading to test failures in
test_compile.py and test_congress.py.
In theory, supporting our custom changes in antlr3 runtime bad, but
because antlr3 is not supported anyway, the situation is really no
worse than before. In addition, the changes are fairly minor.
- antlr4 was not adopted because it does not have support for
abstract syntax trees.

Partially implements blueprint: support-python3

Change-Id: I376aee803c4dc9953c1b5ba9311cf9c4a42f3319

commit_message:
Remove Python 2.6 classifier

We have decided to remove Python 2.6 support, this commit
removes Python 2.6 classifier before dropping any Python
2.6 support in code.

Change-Id: I7f655bcfb59ab7b32274e403837c88956a8a7e1b

Cinder in Debian.

commit_message:
Windows Scheduler

freezer runs the scheduler as a windows service
the service is divided in two parts:
    win_daemon, which interacts with freezer-api and freezer-agent
    win_service, which install freezer scheduler

Change-Id: I148105a7efd3cead6817cbc2dab255451fb3b9a4

commit_message:
Remove Python 2.6 classifier

We have decided to remove Python 2.6 support, this commit
removes Python 2.6 classifier before dropping any Python
2.6 support in code.

Change-Id: I162f4cfc48110d2e54bbfbec2746eb05b6254b0e

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2015-07-08 15:29:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

[{'created': '2015-07-08 15:02:54.000000000', 'message': "Fail when Neutron calls limits APIs.

According to http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/project_scope.html?highlight=proxy#no-more-api-proxies,
Nova APIs shouldn't be used a proxies for in other openstack services.  This fix
raises an HTTPBadRequest (400) exception if Neutron calls the UsedLimits or Limits APIs.

Change-Id: I821aa0a3975f2be879851e9cb556cd6de24e7170
Closes-Bug: #1186354
"}]
commit_message:
Fail when Neutron calls limits APIs.

According to http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/project_scope.html?highlight=proxy#no-more-api-proxies,
Nova APIs shouldn't be used a proxies for in other openstack services.  This fix
raises an HTTPBadRequest (400) exception if Neutron calls the UsedLimits or Limits APIs.

Change-Id: I821aa0a3975f2be879851e9cb556cd6de24e7170
Closes-Bug: #1186354

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-20 15:51:20.000000000', 'message': "Note that BandwidthUsage relates to Instance

It's not obvious (at least I completely missed it) that the uuid field
on BandwidthUsage is a reference to an instance uuid. Renaming the field
instance_uuid would be nice but a lot of work for little benefit, so
let's just put a comment.

Change-Id: I5d5b009f6da9e6c3e176be7cb62c363235978b63
"}]
commit_message:
Note that BandwidthUsage relates to Instance

It's not obvious (at least I completely missed it) that the uuid field
on BandwidthUsage is a reference to an instance uuid. Renaming the field
instance_uuid would be nice but a lot of work for little benefit, so
let's just put a comment.

Change-Id: I5d5b009f6da9e6c3e176be7cb62c363235978b63

commit_message:
Replace Popen4 to Open3 gem

This standard gem (Ruby 2.0 and higher) now support all staff which
Astute required from Popen4.

Change-Id: I7e7bf2b8510d811f73f2235e31522529e8107e93
Closes-Bug: #1518325

commit_message:
neutron-db-manage: mark several options as deprecated

I believe we don't rely on --core_plugin or --quota_driver for the tool
because database contents are independent of chosen plugins and drivers
since ~Juno.

Also marked --service with deprecated_for_removal=True.

Related-Bug: #1501380
Change-Id: I2b4d98242a0d38843d931a71414ef2560a7ddb8f

messages:
[{'account_id': 18445, 'date': '2015-10-14 04:14:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7787, 'date': '2015-10-14 05:06:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Thanks for pushing this. I have a couple of concerns.

First, I want to make sure this has the information to cover both the Godaddy and Rackspace usecases from the bug report. No point in pushing this one if it people still have to carry the custom ones. If you could just get someone to comment on this or the bug report showing that this approach is okay for them, I'm good.

Second, this is tied too heavily to the DB by querying models directly. That will make it possibly incorrect when used with other plugins. Can we at least try to add some ipam methods that provide this information for us so if someone is using a different ipam backend, their driver can provide the correct info?


Finally, with the lightweight controller you have, it's not 100% clear to me that the policy engine can enforce anything on this. Have you confirmed that access to this information can be restricted by policy.json entries?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-10-14 05:50:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

- gate-neutron-python34-constraints http://logs.openstack.org/41/234541/1/check/gate-neutron-python34-constraints/90232f5/ : SUCCESS in 9m 36s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 18445, 'date': '2015-10-14 05:52:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sorry, I actually missed the submission from go-daddy. I have reviewed the submission https://review.openstack.org/#/c/212955. It looks like that submission has a very close model as I am proposing. The few extra items I am looking for are:
1. network-name: needed for monitoring tool
2. support query to select output fields and filters.
3. filter by tenant-id and "shared=[true|false]

I am willing to contribute work based on 212955. 

Can we move forward with 212955?'}, {'account_id': 9060, 'date': '2015-10-14 14:09:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yes, happy to go forward with 212955.  I believe we have an updated patchset coming.  I need to talk to dbingham/wwriverrat and see where that's at.  So maybe we should get that uploaded and then we can start iterating on that one?

We're not opposed to adding more functionality, or tweaking what's there."}, {'account_id': 14374, 'date': '2015-10-14 14:11:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Are there tests for this new endpoint?'}, {'account_id': 18445, 'date': '2015-10-14 15:06:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Good to hear from Mike that we are moving forward with 212955. I will be happy add incremental work on top of that.
Charles, yes, we do have tempest test for the function. But let me watch how 212955 is going.'}, {'account_id': 9060, 'date': '2015-10-14 18:50:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sounds good.  We should have the new patchset up in the next few days.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-11-20 02:17:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

I'd like to look at a single proposal, and [1] has been around for a while, can we put energy and focus in one place, please?

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/212955/"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2015-11-20 02:17:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 18445, 'date': '2015-11-23 15:49:47.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

abandon this change, focus on https://review.openstack.org/212955'}]

commit_message:
Add a driver for Apache Kafka

Adding a driver for Apache Kafka connection, supporting
notification via Kafka.

Change-Id: I79bf70d4a72a1f71cf4d997522de7ca57b05c8e0
Implements: blueprint adding-kafka-support

commit_message:
Update mistral::db::sync to run 'update head'

This patch modifies mistral::db::sync so that it
runs 'update head' instead of 'populate'. We
will likely want to create a new module called
mistral::db::populate that runs just the populate
command.

This brings the mistral "db_sync" class more inline
with other Puppet Openstack modules that run DB sync
and fixes issues in bootstrapping mistral in that
running populate without first having an 'upgrade head'
would always fail.

Change-Id: I9aa02fa8ba2c42aa830c8b0eb556e769b45013f4

commit_message:
Integration of Ceilometer in Watcher

In current implementation is not easy to use ceilometer.
Watcher must query metrics from the Telemetry v2 API to allow an easiest integration with OpenStack components (especially devstack).

blueprint telemetry-integration
Change-Id: Ide515472f1d160925d9f4aabf48c96dea4f6bc05

commit_message:
Make VPN functional jobs voting

Now that the VPN functional jobs running with the new job template have been
running non-voting, we can re-add the jobs to the gate queue and make them
voting.

Verified that the jobs, using the new template, ran with a Neutron commit,
using experimental job (see review 242222/6).

Later, based on community decision, the VPN functional job for StrongSwan
can be moved from Neutron experimental queue, to a voting queue.

Change-Id: I809ef7e61eaddcbfd11c26b218c784622f588c1d
Partial-Bug: 1495584

I don't think we should mandate exporting the stack before an abandon action can be performed.  Abandon is useful as a "force delete", in case you have a resource that won't delete but you need to remove the stack anyway.  Or, you might want to delete the stack and keep the resources around but don't care about the stack data.  In both situations, exporting the stack would be an unnecessary step.

However, if a user is trying to migrate the stack to another Heat instance, they can still export (and try again, if necessary) before doing the abandon.'}, {'account_id': 10487, 'date': '2015-06-22 11:55:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Jason, kindly refer the below defect, filed as high priority defect to mandate the export as the pre-step for the abandon

https://launchpad.net/bugs/1353670 has more details.

This will completely save user from loosing the stack data.'}, {'account_id': 7253, 'date': '2015-06-22 15:27:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Kanagaraj, mandating the export isn't necessary to fix the bug.  In fact, it could give the user a false sense of security because the export data could still be lost in transmission, yet the stack would be in "export complete" status.  I can't think of a reason to mandate exporting the data first.  The user should be able to attempt an export zero or more times (depending on their use case and whether or not they received all of the export data) prior to abandoning.'}, {'account_id': 10487, 'date': '2015-06-23 15:53:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Zaneb & Jason, I see there is an contradiction in the opinion of how we want to provide the dependency between abandon and export. and both are expected behaviour from user point of view. some user may wants to force this dependency while others don't want.

So, we could make it as configurable tag for a given stack by user. if user sets the flag as mandatory then stack won't be allowed to abandon until, it get exported successfully and and mark the tag as proceed to abandon. I feel it gives control the user on how (s)he wants.

Kindly let me know your comment on this. Thanks."}, {'account_id': 10487, 'date': '2015-06-24 11:41:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Workflow-1

This has been discussed in todays #openstack-meetings heat meeting and decided to use --force flag as part of abandon, and if force is provided , abandon will be executed for sure. otherwise only fo r exported stack, abandon will be allowed.'}, {'account_id': 10487, 'date': '2015-06-24 12:12:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-06-24 12:47:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Verified-1

Dear Jason,

I believe that #1353670 is filed to make the export as mandatory before abandon and you have suggested to make it as optional. so we try to balance the both the option as both could be an valid user case and came up with new approach by introducing the param --force, which will help the user who wants to forcefully abandon the stack without exporting. 

Now by default we made the export is an mandatory as it makes the user to export the data. And one who wants to forcefully abandon, can go with --force.

I believe this answers your concerns. kindly let me know otherwise. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 10487, 'date': '2015-07-02 07:47:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 10487, 'date': '2015-07-02 08:09:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-07-02 08:49:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Verified+1
